Solution to Question 1:
A newborn is usually hypermetropic by +2D to +3D.
The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the eyeball at birth is about 16.5 mm, which is about 70% of the adult size. This reduced axial length causes light to converge behind the retina, leading to
hypermetropia.
Additionally, the corneal diameter at birth is 10 mm. The adult size (11.7 mm) is attained by 2 years of age. The orbit is more divergent (50°) as compared to adult (45°).
Note: The lacrimal glands are underdeveloped in a newborn and, hence, do not secrete tears.
Solution to Question 2:
Full visual acuity is attained by the age of 6 years. Important milestones in visual development are:
At birth, there is no central fixation, and the eyes move randomly.
By the first month of life, the fixation reflex starts developing and becomes established by 6 months.
By 3 months, binocular vision is established.
By 6 months, macular stereopsis and accommodation reflex are fully developed.
By 6 years of age, full visual acuity (6/6) is attained.

Solution to Question 11:
The condition depicted in the image is a coloboma of the iris, and the most common site of coloboma is the inferonasal quadrant.
A coloboma is a congenital malformation in one of the structures in the eye, such as the iris, retina, choroid, or optic disc, due to the failure of embryonic fissure closure. Coloboma of the uveal tract may be typical (seen in the inferonasal quadrant) or atypical (occasionally found in other positions). Typical coloboma is of two types:
Complete: Extends from pupil to optic nerve, causing a corresponding lens indentation.
Incomplete: May involve iris alone, or iris and ciliary body (more common), or iris, ciliary bod and a part of choroid.
Other embryonic remnants in the eye:
Mittendorf's dot - Remnant of the anterior end of the hyaloid arter
Bergmeister papilla - Remnant of the posterior end of the hyaloid arter
Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) - Failure of fetal vasculature to regress The image below shows a fundoscopy view of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.

Solution to Question 12:
The image shows a coloboma of the optic disc, accompanied by a large chorioretinal coloboma located below the optic disc, which is caused by incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure.
This developmental anomaly may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris. Coloboma of the optic disc can present in two forms: a minor effect often associated with refractive errors like hypermetropia and astigmatism and a fully developed coloboma that appears as a large inferonasal whitish excavation resembling the optic disc.
Defective vision and superior visual field defects are typically associated with fully developed coloboma. Additionally, this condition may be associated with chorioretinal coloboma, a congenital anomaly where the developing optic cup fails to fuse completely, leading to abnormal choroidal and retinal development.
Note: Faulty migration of neural crest cells results in anterior segment dysgenesis.

Solution to Question 14:
The optic foramen is situated between the two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid.
The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is formed medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa.
The optic canal transmits the optic nerve with its meningeal coverings; the ophthalmic artery, which is below the nerve, is embedded in its dural sheath, and a few twigs from the sympathetic plexus accompanying the artery.

Solution to Question 15:
In the given clinical scenario, a fracture of the optic canal is most likely to damage the ophthalmic artery and optic nerve, as these are the primary structures passing through it.
The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is a short cylindrical structure bounded medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa, serving as a pathway for the aforementioned structures along with its sympathetic plexus.
Optic canal fractures, often associated with basilar skull fractures, can lead to optic neuropathy. The intracanalicular and intracranial portion of the optic nerve is most commonly affected in head trauma.
Note: The greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bound the superior orbital fissure.

Solution to Question 17:
The posterior chamber of the eyeball is filled with aqueous humor.
The eyeball is divided into anterior and posterior segments. The anterior segment includes the lens and the structures anterior to it, such as the cornea, iris and two aqueous humor-filled spaces:
Anterior chamber: Located between cornea and iris, contains aqueous humor and communicates with the posterior chamber through the pupil.
Posterior chamber: Triangular-shaped space, also contains aqueous humor, bounded anteriorl by the posterior surface of the iris, laterally by the ciliary body, and posteriorly by the lens.
The posterior segment includes all structures located posterior to the lens, comprising of the vitreous humor, retina, choroid and optic disc.

Solution to Question 18:

Lateral orbital tubercle or Whitnall's tubercle is a small elevation on the orbital surface of the zygomatic bone, just within the lateral orbital margin. It is about 11 mm below the
fronto-zygomatic suture.
Four structures are attached to it:
Check ligament of the lateral rectus
Lockwood’s ligament (Suspensory ligament of the eyeball)
Lateral palpebral ligament
Lateral horn of the levator aponeurosis
The Whitnall's ligament or the superior transverse ligament of the eye, is attached to the superior tarsal plate and the orbital bone.

Solution to Question 19:
The tarsal plates are not cartilaginous structures but firm, dense connective tissue (fibrous tissue) plates.
The tarsal plates serve as the structural support of the eyelids. The height of the upper tarsal plate is about 10 mm, and that of the lower tarsal plate is 4 mm. Both plates have a thickness of about 1
mm. The ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments (medial and lateral canthal tendons). The levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of the upper tarsal plate.
The meibomian glands are located within the tarsus. These are holocrine-secreting sebaceous glands that are not associated with lash follicles.

Solution to Question 10:
The given figure is a Sturm's conoid. It represents a bundle of light rays formed by a regularly astigmatic surface. The image is clearest or least confusing as point D, the circle of least confusion.
When light passes through a regularly astigmatic surface(surface with toric curvature), vertical and horizontal rays converge at different points.
The distance between the points of convergence (focus) of the vertical and horizontal rays is called the focal interval of strum. (distance between points B and F). The circle of least confusion/ circle of diffusion lies at the mid-point of this interval.
F r the given Sturm's conoid,
At point A, a horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays converge more rapidly than horizontal rays.
At point B, vertical rays come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging; so, it will be a horizontal straight line.
At points C, D, and E, the vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging.
At point D, the vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged; so, we get a perfect circle called the circle of least confusion.
At point E, a vertical oval is formed.
At point F, a vertical straight line is formed
At point G and beyond, both rays are diverging, and we always get a vertical oval/prolate ellipse.

The visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum for the human eye is 400–700 nm. Theories of color vision:
Trichromatic theory (Young–Helmholtz theory) assumes that there are three types of color receptors. Each receptor is assumed to respond to all wavelengths, however, each has different spectral sensitivities.
Opponent process theory, also known as the Hering theory, assumes three sets of receptor systems—red-green, blue-yellow, and black-white. Each one of these functions as an antagonistic pair (e.g., red light stimulates the red receptors and, at the same time, inhibits the green).
Edwin Land's theory has three separate color systems (retinexes). Each is an analog to a black-and-white picture.

The Floccular nucleus of the cerebellum controls ocular saccades.
A saccade is a rapid ballistic movement to change the point of fixation. It is the fastest of all eye movements and is initiated by the contralateral frontal lobe. Smooth pursuit is a slow tracking movement to keep the target on the fovea. It is controlled by the ipsilateral parieto-occipital lobe.
F llowing an object from the right to left is left pursuit and is controlled by ipsilateral (left) parieto-occipital lobe, and the corrective movement is a saccade (in this case, left to right) termed right saccade and is controlled by the contralateral (left) frontal lobe.
The floccular nucleus is found in the lobule HX of the cerebellar vermis. Its functions include matching pulse-step, gaze holding, and sustained smooth pursuit. Bilateral lesions of the flocculus result in the following:
Post-saccadic drift- saccadic movements do not stop, but there is a brief, several hundred milliseconds drift of the eyes after each saccade.
Saccadic pursuit- smooth tracking is replaced by simultaneous rapid jerking motions of the eye to follow an object toward the ipsilateral visual field.
Gaze-evoked nystagmus- impaired ability to hold the eyes in the eccentric position, resulting in gaze-evoked nystagmus towards the affected side of the cerebellum.
Emboliform and globose nuclei: Generation of vertical saccades Fastigial nuclei: Pursuit initiation

Solution to Question 1:
Abnormalities of the curvature of the cornea is the most common cause of astigmatism.
Astigmatism is a refractive error in which the rays of light entering the eye are refracted differently in different meridia of the eye. Meridia of the eye correspond to the lines of longitude on a globe.
There are two types of astigmatism. In regular astigmatism, refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. In irregular astigmatism, there is irregular change of the refractive power in different meridia. It can be caused by corneal scars.
Etiology of regular astigmatism:
Corneal: Most common cause. Occurs due to abnormalities of curvature of the cornea
Lenticular: Occurs due to abnormalities of lens curvature and position
Curvatural: Seen in lenticonus
Positional: Due to tilting or oblique placement of the lens or subluxation of lens
Retinal: Due to oblique placement of the macula

Note: Spherical aberration is a high-order refractive error of the eye. It is seen when light rays passing through the periphery of the cornea and lens focus at a slightly different location than ight rays passing through the center of the cornea and lens. It improves on using a pinhole.

Solution to Question 2:
With-the-rule astigmatism is normally seen in the eyes due to the pressure of the eyelids.
In with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is more curved. This is more common and often occurs due to the pressure of eyelids on the eye. In against-the-rule astigmatism (ATR) (option B), the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian. In both these types, the principal meridia are vertical and horizontal (90 and 180 degrees) and are at right angles to each other.

With-the-rule astigmatism is the type of astigmatism wherein the vertical curvature is always more than the horizontal curvature. Thus, irrespective of the type or cause of with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is always more myopic (curved) than the horizontal meridian.

Astigmatism is a refractive error in which the rays of light entering the eye are refracted differently in different meridia of the eye. Meridia of the eye correspond to the lines of longitude on a globe. There are two types of astigmatism - regular and irregular.
In regular astigmatism, refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. Thus, two principal meridia are present. The rays of light from infinity form two focal points due to the difference in curvature of the two principal meridia. Based on the relation of the two focal points to the retina, regular astigmatism has the following types:
Simple astigmatism: One focal point lies on the retina. In simple myopic type, the second foca point lies in front of the retina while in simple hypermetropic type, the second focal point lies behind the retina.
Compound astigmatism: In compound hypermetropic type, both focal points lie behind the retina. In compound myopic type, both focal points lie in front of the retina.
Mixed astigmatism: One focal point lies in front of while the second focal point lies behind the retina.

Roving-ring scotoma:

The edge of a convex lens acts as a prism. The greater the angle of the prism, the more will be the bending. In aphakic spectacles, the angle of the lens is large. Thus, the light falling at the edge of the lens bends towards the center of the lens and does not reach the pupil. This results in a
ring-shaped scotoma as this prismatic effect is present all around the edges of the lens. The position of this scotoma is not fixed in the visual field because the eye keeps moving (or roving) in relation to the aphakic spectacle. Hence, the result is a roving ring scotoma.

Solution to Question 1:
Lamina fusca is the innermost layer of the sclera.
Lamina fusca faces the choroid. It is the transition zone between the sclera and the choroid. It consists of a delicate meshwork of elastic fibres, fibrocytes and melanocytes, traversed by long posterior ciliary nerves and vessels.
Layers of the sclera from outside to inside include episclera, sclera proper, and lamina fusca, in that order.

Solution to Question 3:
The lateral limbus is the least likely site to be involved in a traumatic scleral rupture.
Traumatic scleral rupture, or globe rupture, occurs after blunt-force trauma. It usually occurs due to the compression force of the trauma. It therefore likely occurs at the insertion of rectus muscles, at the equator, or in an area parallel to the limbus opposite from the site of the impact. Rupture at the site of trauma, in this case lateral limbus, is rare.
The major signs of scleral rupture are conjunctival edema and subconjunctival hemorrhage, hyphema, ocular hypotony, impairment or dislocation of the lens, vitreous hemorrhage, and retinal detachment.

Anterior scleritis is further classified into the following types:

Solution to Question 1:
The corneal epithelium is made up of stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium.

Layers of the cornea:
Epithelium (Stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium)
Bowman’s membrane - Acellular; does not regenerate
Stroma (Thickest layer) - The stroma can scar, but cannot regenerate
Dua’s layer (Newly discovered, toughest layer)
Descemet’s membrane- Ends peripherally as Schwalbe’s ring; has regenerative potential
Endothelium (Most metabolically active layer)- does not regenerate
Note: Limbal stem cells are located at the corneoscleral limbus, in the palisades of Vogt. Deficiency may result in chronic epithelial defects and "conjunctivalization" of the cornea
Solution to Question 2:
The hydration level and transparency of the cornea is maintained mainly by the endothelial cells of the cornea.
The endothelium possesses Na+/K+ ATPase, which keeps the corneal stroma in a relatively dehydrated state. This helps maintain corneal transparency. Endothelial cells decrease in number with age. If the cornea becomes overhydrated, it begins to scatter light and gradually begins to lose its transparency
Other factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are as follows:
Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae (Maurice theory)
The peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory)
Avascularity of the cornea
A balance between the intraocular pressure (IOP) and swelling pressure The different layers of the cornea are as follows:
Epithelium
Bowman’s membrane
Stroma (substantia propria)
Dua’s layer (pre-Descemet’s layer)
Descemet’s membrane
Endothelium
Solution to Question 3:
The density of corneal endothelial cells in adults is about 2500–3000 cells/mm².
Variation in corneal endothelial density with age:
At birth- 3,500–4,000 cells/mm2 at birth
Young adults- 2500–3000 cells/mm²
Old age (about 80 years)- 2000 cells/mm²
Corneas stored in eye banks are assessed for their quality and viability using a variety of parameters. Donor tissues are screened for stress lines, mechanical trauma, scarring, corneal edema, and infiltrates that could indicate poor tissue quality. They are further evaluated for thickness and endothelial cell density (a surrogate for endothelial function) which are important determinants of successful graft transplantation.
Endothelial cell density (ECD) and morphology are assessed using a specular microscope or by a bright-field/phase-contrast light microscope.
Note: The number of cells decreases at about 0.6% per year, and the neighboring cells enlarge to fill the space as the cells cannot regenerate. At a density of about 500 cells/mm2, corneal edema develops and transparency is impaired. This is known as critical endothelial density.

The sudden onset and rapid progression of ocular symptoms and ulceration in this patient along with the history of improper contact lens usage are suggestive of a Pseudomonas infection.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common gram-negative organism isolated from corneal ulcers and is a frequent cause of contact lens–associated keratitis. Other risk factors include chlorinated swimming pools, hot tubs, ventilators, nebulizer, and vaporizer solutions, and ophthalmic solution bottles.
Pseudomonas keratitis has a rapid and fulminant course if left untreated and are associated with a worse visual prognosis than that caused by most other common bacterial
pathogens. Pseudomonas spp. can cause corneal perforation in just 48 hours. Treatment is mainly by topical NSAIDs and topical antipseudomonal antibiotic eye drops such as tobramycin 1.3% and fluoroquinolone eye drops.

Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical vignette of the patient presenting with pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye following trauma by a vegetative matter is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer.
Fungal corneal ulcer also known as mycotic keratitis is usually caused by trauma from vegetative matter such as branches of trees, leaves and animal tails. Injudicious use of topical steroids and antibiotics increases the predisposition to develop secondary fungal keratitis.
Mycotic keratitis can be caused by
Filamentous fungi such as Aspergillus and Fusarium
Yeasts such as Candida and cryptococcus
Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma and Blastomyces
Typically in fungal corneal ulcers, the signs are more prominent than the symptoms. The symptoms of fungal keratitis are similar to that of bacterial ulcers which include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, blurred vision, and redness of the eyes.
A typical fungal ulcer has the following signs:
Greyish white looking dry corneal ulcer with rolled out margin.
Feathery finger-like extensions into the corneal stroma under intact epithelium
Wessley ring which is a sterile immune ring that occurs due to the deposition of immune complexes
Multiple small satellite lesions around the ulcer
Hypopyon: The hypopyon in fungal ulcer is immobile and unsterile unlike bacterial ulcer (sterile hypopyon)
Perforation is rare
Corneal vascularization is usually absent.
A diagnosis of fungal ulcer is made by a typical history of trauma with vegetative matter followed by clinical examination and KOH mount or SDA agar cultures from corneal scrappings.

Clinically, fungi are classified on a morphological basis into filamentous, yeast, and dimorphic forms:
Filamentous organisms are multicellular with branched hyphae. It can be septate or aseptate.
Septate filamentous organisms, such as Fusarium and Aspergillus, have hyphae that are divided by cell walls.
Non-septate filamentous fungi, include Mucor and Rhizopus.
Yeasts, such as Candida and Cryptococcus, are unicellular fungi that reproduce by budding, but in tissue, they might develop elongated buds (pseudohyphae).
Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma, Coccidioides, and Blastomyces demonstrate both a yeast phase that occurs in tissues and a mycelial phase that appears on culture media and saprophytic surfaces.

Solution to Question 1:
Band-shaped keratopathy is caused by pathological calcium deposition on the cornea in the form of a band.
On exam, there is a white band-like formation of calcium across the corneal surface with irregular borders and a peripheral clearing of cornea between the calcium deposits and the limbus. Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.
The pathogenesis is not fully known. Several associations have been identified, which include rigid contact lens wear, chronic eye rubbing, Down's syndrome, atopic disease, Leber's congenital amaurosis, and connective tissue disease.
It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often causes significant myopia and irregular astigmatism.
Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool for KCN detection.
Whereas keratoplasty, historically has been the mainstay of treatment for keratoconus, it is now generally reserved for eyes that are unable to achieve functional vision with other surgical or
non-surgical modalities and is only considered only as a last resort, in very advanced disease. It is the definitive treatment for keratoconus, not the treatment of choice.

Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory, bilateral corneal ectasia characterized by
cone-like steepening due to irregular stromal thinning. This leads to a conical corneal protrusion, significant vision loss, myopia and irregular astigmatism.
The available options for the management of keratoconus are highly dependent on the stage of the disease and its progression. If the disease is stabilized (no progression), the emphasis is given to correcting the vision. If the disease is progressing, the emphasis is on slowing (arresting) the progression.

Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses and vaulting scleral lenses are the mainstays of vision treatment for moderate to advanced KCN. Solution to Question 1:
The inner plexiform layer is the marked layer in the given histological image of retina, identified as the fourth layer from the uppermost (innermost) layer.
The retina consists of 10 layers. The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is the outermost layer - below the Bruch's membrane of the choroid - and the internal limiting membrane is the innermost layer - separating the retina from the vitreous.
The retinal pigment epithelium consists of a single layer of cells containing pigment. It is separated from the neurosensory retinal layers by the potential space between them which is known as interphotoreceptor matrix.
The inner plexiform layer consists of synapsing nerve fibers. The axons of bipolar cells synapse with dendrites of ganglion cells; and both these processes synapse with processes
of amacrine cells. It also contains some horizontally placed internal plexiform cells; and also a few ganglion cells.

Solution to Question 2:
The marked structure in the slide is the outer plexiform layer of the retina.
The outer plexiform layer (outer synaptic layer) is present between the outer nuclear layer and the inner nuclear layer. This layer stains lightly. This layer consists of the axons of rods and cones which synapse with dendrites of bipolar neurons and horizontal cells.

Solution to Question 3:
The distance of the fovea from the temporal margin of the optic disc is 2 disc diameters.
The fovea is an excavation in the retinal surface at the center of the macula, with a diameter of 1.5 mm, which is about the same as that of the optic disc. The foveola forms the bottom of the fovea and has a diameter of 0.35 mm. It is devoid of ganglion cells. The umbo is the central floor the foveola, which corresponds to the foveolar light reflex. The foveal avascular zone (FAZ) is a central area (including foveola and surrounding areas) which contains no blood vessels but is surrounded by a continuous network of capillaries.
The macula is a round area at the posterior pole, lying inside the temporal vascular arcades. It measures 5.5 mm in diameter. The inner layers of the macula contain the yellow xanthophyll carotenoid pigments lutein and zeaxanthin in far higher concentrations than the peripheral retina (hence, the full name "macula lutea", which means yellow plaque).

Solution to Question 4:
Optic disc hypoplasia does not cause enlargement of the blind spot.
The physiological blind spot is an area of absolute scotoma in the visual field, seen in the region of optic disc. It is due to the absence of photoreceptors (rods and cones) in that region. Enlarged blind spot is seen in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) (Option A), papilledema (Option C), medullated nerve fibers (Option D), optic disc drusen, coloboma of optic disc and
myopic disc with a crescent.
Optic nerve hypoplasia is the most common congenital optic disc anomaly. There is underdevelopment of the optic disc in the disease and it typically presents with a small disc that is surrounded by a yellowish pigmented ring, called the 'double ring sign'.
Option A: In primary open-angle glaucoma(POAG), the optic disc enlargement is seen secondary to increased intra-ocular pressure (IOP) in the eye.
Option C: Papilledema is a passive disc swelling seen with raised intracranial pressure. The blind spot is enlarged due to the edema of the optic disc.
Option D: Medullated or opaque nerve fibers are the abnormal myelination of nerve fibers of the retina. Normally, optic nerve myelination stops at the level of lamina cribrosa. If the myelination continues beyond the optic disc it leads to the expansion of the blind spot. On ophthalmoscopic examination, these are seen as a whitish patch with feathery margins.
Solution to Question 5:
The nuclei of Müller cells lie in the inner nuclear layer.
Müller cells are a type of macroglial cells of the retina. The human retina contains 8–10 million Müller cells. Their nuclei lie in the inner nuclear layer and their processes extend across the retinal layers to form the inner and outer limiting membranes. Their functions include:
Providing structural stability to the retina
Interacting with other neurons and their functional and metabolic support
Providing neurons with trophic substances and removing metabolic waste
Playing a critical role in regulating the extracellular space volume as well as ion and water omeostasis and in maintaining the inner blood-retinal barrier
Astrocytes are another type of macroglial cells of the retina. They play a crucial role in retinal vascularization. In the mature retina, they are restricted to the nerve fiber and ganglion cell layers.
Solution to Question 6:
Retinal vessels reach temporal ora at approximately 40 weeks of gestation.
Retinal vessels develop de novo from mesenchymal tissue, beginning during the 4th month of gestation. They radiate outward (centrifugally) from the optic nerve, reaching the nasal ora by 36 weeks.
Solution to Question 7:
A preterm baby, treated for respiratory distress syndrome, with leucocoria (white pupillary reflex) most likely has retrolental fibroplasia.
Retrolental fibroplasia, also known as retinopathy of prematurity, is a proliferative retinopathy. Risk factors include prematurity, very low birth weight and supplemental oxygen therapy (given for respiratory distress syndrome). ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead to blindness in serious cases.

Solution to Question 8:
ROP stage 3 extending from 2'0 clock to 7'o clock (6 clock hours) in zone 2 with plus disease fits into the definition of threshold disease.
Threshold disease of retinopathy of prematurity is defined by the CRYO-ROP study as:
Stage 3 disease: Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous
Involvement of zones 1 or 2
Involvement of either at least 5 contiguous (continuous) clock hours or 8 non-contiguous clock ours
Associated with "plus disease": Dilatation and tortuosity of posterior pole vessels in at least two quadrants at the posterior pole.
Treatment of threshold disease is laser photocoagulation of the involved part within 72 hours of diagnosis.

Treatment of the various stages of ROP includes:
Pre-threshold type 1 disease - Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours and is done by laser photocoagulation of avascular retina.
Pre-threshold type 2 disease (Any ROP not following under type 1)- Observation for progression
Threshold disease - Laser photocoagulation of avascular retina
Aggresive posterior-ROP- Intravitreal anti-VEGF agents, eg., bevacizumab
Tractional retinal detachment (stage 4A) - Pars plana vitrectomy
Solution to Question 9:
Neonates are best examined in the neonatal unit itself under the supervision of the attending neonatologist. It is not recommended to transport infants to the ophthalmic outpatient department for examination.
The first screening examination should be carried out by indirect ophthalmoscopy at 32 weeks PMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later. For infants born at less than 28 weeks, screening is done at 3 weeks PNA to detect APROP. Aggressive posterior ROP ("rush" disease, AP-ROP), if untreated, usually progresses to total retinal detachment (stage 5) within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease and ill-defined nature of the retinopathy.

Solution to Question 10:
Subtotal retinal detachment is considered to be stage 4 of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).
The clinical staging of ROP is as follows:
Stage 1 - Formation of a demarcation line at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
Stage 2- Formation of an intraretinal ridge
Stage 3- Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous
Stage 4- Subtotal retinal detachment
Stage 5- Total retinal detachment

Solution to Question 11:
In the scenario above, the postnatal age of the premature infant is 2 weeks, and therefore, the infant must be screened in 2 weeks i.e., 4 weeks of postnatal age, as per the guidelines for the management of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).
ROP guidelines state that the first examination should be performed between 4 and 6 weeks of postnatal age (after birth) or between 31–33 weeks of post-conceptional age (calculated as gestational age + postnatal age), whichever is later. Ideally, 2 examinations must be performed; however, 1 may suffice if it shows complete retinal vascularisation.

Solution to Question 12:
The most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy is the duration of diabetes.
Diabetic retinopathy constitutes the retinal changes seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The most important factor for its development is duration of diabetes after the onset of puberty, followed by glycemic control. It is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus. The presence of hypertension increases the risk of diabetic retinopathy.
First fundus examination for type 1 diabetes is done after 5 years after diagnosis and for type 2 is done at the time of diagnosis. The frequency of follow-up for types 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus is every year. Diabetes in pregnancy is followed up every 3 months.
The earliest feature of diabetic retinopathy is microaneurysms, which are present in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
Solution to Question 13:
Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants is a feature of severe NPDR. Note: Macular star is a feature of malignant hypertensive retinopathy.

Solution to Question 14:
A 45 year old diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is likely to have type 2 diabetes and thus, he should undergo screening for diabetic retinopathy immediately.
Duration of diabetes is the most important risk factor for developing diabetic retinopathy, especially proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The recommendations for first fundus examination in diabetic retinopathy is:
Within 3-5 years of diagnosis in type 1 diabetes
Immediately in type 2 diabetes.
Later, the screening is continued once every year in both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes. In the event proliferative diabetic retinopathy develops, screening is done more frequently - once every 2 months.
Solution to Question 15:
Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a randomized clinical trial that studied the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.
The results of the study demonstrated the beneficial effects of focal photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema. The study resulted in the recommendation that all eyes with clinically significant diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.
Solution to Question 16:
The fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) image shows enlarged foveal avascular zone, seen as a hypofluorescent patch in the macula (white arrow), with surrounding capillary non perfused areas (blue arrow). Both of these are suggestive of macular ischemia.

The above mentioned findings when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points towards the diagnosis of diabetic macular ischemia.
FFA images in a case of diabetic retinopathy are given below:

Punctate or pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence - microaneurysms
Abnormal branching of arteriovenous shunt - intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)

Option B: Macular edema also known as cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in the blood-retina barrier. On fundoscopy, a honeycomb appearance is seen, and on FFA, flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image shows the flower petal pattern on FFA as seen in CME.

Solution to Question 17:
A patient with hypertension having "silver wiring," papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visible on fundoscopy has Grade IV retinopathy.

Solution to Question 18:
Systolic hypertension (systolic blood pressure over 200 mm Hg) with bilateral blurry vision and unremarkable examination findings point to a diagnosis of hypertensive retinopathy. Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) are not seen in hypertensive retinopathy. IRMA is a feature of diabetic retinopathy.
Arteriolar narrowing occurs due to vasoconstriction and sclerosis of retinal vessels due to hypertension. Cotton wool spots are areas of nerve fibre layer infarcts. They occur due to capillary obliteration in hypertension.

Solution to Question 19:
The image shows multiple cotton wool spots around the disc. This is Purtschers' retinopathy, which is classically associated with severe head injury.
It is also seen in pancreatitis and chest trauma due to fat/air embolism. Ophthalmoscopy reveals multiple, variably sized cotton-wool spots and intraretinal hemorrhages around the optic nerve. There is no effective treatment.
Solution to Question 20:
Hemoglobin SC and S-Thal disease have the most severe ocular manifestations, although sickle SS disease has the most severe systemic manifestations.
The incidence of proliferative retinopathy in SC disease (Hb SC) is 33%, sickle cell thalassemia (Hb S-Thal) is 14%, SS disease (Hb SS) is 3%. In sickle cell retinopathy, elevated blood viscosity may occlude venules and arterioles, as well as capillaries. The following fundus findings can be noted as a result:
Retinal vascular peripheral non-perfusion
Retinal hemorrhages: "salmon patches," "iridescent spots," and "black sunbursts" are hallmarks of nonproliferative sickle cell retinopathy.
Peripheral retinal neovascularization in a "sea fan" configuration is the hallmark of proliferative sickle cell retinopathy. They are also described as "parachute" lesions. They are most commonly found in the supero-temporal vascular arcades.
Angioid streaks (Rupture of Bruch’s membrane)
Conjunctival "comma-shaped" capillaries and iris atrophy are other ocular findings seen. Complications of sickle cell retinopathy include central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) (occurs due to retinal hypoxia), vitreous hemorrhage and tractional retinal detachment.
The image below shows 'sea fans' as seen on fluorescein angiography.

Solution to Question 21:
Roth's spots are seen in acute leukemia.
Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale center. The white centre due to coagulated fibrin-platelet plug is surrounded by red rim that is caused by hemorrhage. Roth's spots may be seen in:
Subacute bacterial endocarditis
Leukemia
Diabetes
Sickle cell retinopathy
Hypertensive retinopathy
HIV retinopathy
Systemic lupus erythematosus
The fundus image below shows Roth's spots.

Option B: Uveal melanoma devolps due to malignant transformation of the normal melanocytes present in the uveal tissue. Primary posterior uveal melanoma (choroidal melanoma) which forms the majority of uveal melanoma manifests as:
A solitary elevated subretinal grey-brown dome shaped mass
"Collar stud" appearance on B-scan - when the tumor breaks through the Bruchs membrane and protrudes into subretinal space
"Double circulation" sign
Primary anterior uveal melanoma frequently involves the iris and presents as nodular melanocytic mass on the iris. The below given fundus image shows the "double circulation sign" of choroidal melanoma.

Option C: Uveal lymphoma is characterized by localized or diffuse uveal infiltrates of malignant lymphoma cells. Fundus examination in these patients show diffuse creamy thickening of posterior uvea with nodular accentuation.
Solution to Question 22:
Unilateral decreased vision with retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates and telangiectatic vessels in a young boy points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.
Coats’ disease, described by Coats in 1908, affects boys three times more often than girls, has no reported racial or ethnic predilection, and is usually unilateral. The average age at diagnosis is 8–16 years. The clinical course is generally progressive.
It is characterized by discrete zones of retinal vascular abnormalities like aneurysmal dilatation and leakage. It is associated with localized lipid deposition (hard exudates) and varying degrees of subretinal exudates. Vessels may appear telangiectatic, and they may have aneurysms that are grape-like, clustered, or light bulb-shaped.
The image below depicts the typical vascular abnormalities with aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe lipid deposition in the macula which are seen in Coat's disease.

Solution to Question 23:
Monocular blurring of vision and pain with "splashed sauce" appearance on fundoscopy points towards a diagnosis of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).
Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterised by sudden visual loss. There is splashed sauce appearance on fundoscopy due to retinal hemorrhages. Risk factors include high intraocular pressure (IOP), hypertension and blood viscosity syndromes.
Its complications include neovascularisation of the iris (rubeosis iridis) and neovascular glaucoma (NVG). NVG typically occurs 3 months after the occlusive event. Up to 50% of eyes develop NVG following ischaemic CRVO. Pan-retinal photocoagulation is the treatment of choice.
CRVO is classified into two types:
Ischemic CRVO: Characterized by relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), markedly reduced visual acuity, and many cotton-wool spots
Non-ischemic CRVO: Characterized by normal pupillary reaction, reduced visual acuity, and few cotton-wool spots
Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.
Solution to Question 24:
The image above demonstrates characteristic flame-shaped hemorrhages, localized to the superotemporal sector of the retina. The image, along with loss of vision and history of hypertension, points to a diagnosis of branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO), specifically affecting the superotemporal branch of the retinal vein.
Occlusion of a single branch of the retinal vein leads to branched retinal vein occlusion. This occlusion leads to impaired venous drainage, resulting in the accumulation of blood within the retina. The visual defect in BRVO tends to be partial.
Note: The different types of retinal vascular obstructions are branched retinal vein obstruction (BRVO), central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO), branched retinal artery obstruction (BRAO) and central retinal artery obstruction (CRAO). Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is the second most common retinal vascular disorder after diabetic retinopathy.
In CRVO, tortuosity and engorgement of all branches of the central retinal vein are seen, affecting all quadrants of the retina.
Solution to Question 25:
Sudden painless unilateral vision loss with carotid bruit (carotid artery disease) and the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The best immediate step in management is ocular massage among the given options.
Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. Risk factors include heart disease, carotid artery disease, mucormycosis, varicella infection, radiation exposure and trauma. It may be caused by the following:
Emboli of carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli
Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
Retinal arteritis with obliteration
Angiospasm
Raised intraocular pressure
Thrombophilic disorders
Patients often present with sudden painless monocular loss of vision with history of a similar episode that resolved spontaneously (amaurosis fugax). On examination, direct pupillary reflex is absent and relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive. Fundus examination shows marked attenuation of arteries (thread like arteries), interrupted blood flow in vein (cattle
track appearance), cherry red spot, severe edema and retinal pallor.
A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence of ganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This in contrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of the normal choroidal color.
Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by IV acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.
Solution to Question 26:
A 52-year-old woman temporal headaches, myalgias and pain in the jaw while chewing likely has giant cell arteritis (GCA). Given that she has sudden painless monocular loss of vision with RAPD and points to a diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).
GCA is the most common primary vasculitis in adults. It is a risk factor for the development of CRAO. CRAO occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. When obstruction to the blood flow is not complete, the flow may be partially restored. Thus, gentle pressure upon the globe may break the column of venous blood into red beads separated by clear interspaces. This gives the characteristic 'cattle truck' appearance.
Option A: Ischemic CRVO shows a characteristic "splashed tomato sauce" appearance on fundoscopy.
Option C: Non-Ischemic CRVO does not present with such a severe loss of visual acuity. Option D: Branched retinal artery occlusion presents with hemifield visual defects.
Solution to Question 27:
Sudden painless monocular loss of vision with fundoscopy showing Hollehorst
plaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen in these cases.
Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels.
Note: Although elevated intraocular pressure has been implicated as a cause of central retinal artery obstruction, it is unlikely that intraocular pressure can be raised high enough to block arterial inflow to the eye

Solution to Question 28:
The prodromal symptoms of flashing lights, floaters followed by loss of monocular vision (curtain over the eye) and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between NSR and RPE due to a retinal tear.
Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the most common type of retinal detachment. It occurs due to fluid accumulation after a retinal break (tear). High myopia, trauma, pseudophakia, aphakia are predisposing factors. Patients present with photopsia (flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break), floaters and visual field defect (black curtain/veil in front of the eye).
Signs include hypotony, as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE and Shafers sign or tobacco dusting (pigments in the anterior vitreous). The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations. The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear and the most dangerous location of retinal break is the
supero-temporal retina.
Treatment is by prophylactic laser barrage, scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy and pars plana vitrectomy.
Other types of retinal detachment are tractional and exudative type:
Tractional retinal detachment occurs when fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. It is seen in proliferative
diabetic retinopathy, central retinal venous occlusion, Eales disease and ROP. The detached retina is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen. Treatment is with pars plana vitrectomy with endo photocoagulation.
Exudative retinal detachment is seen when exudative fluid from the choroid collects in the subretinal space. Patients present with visual field defects, floaters due to vitritis but no
photopsia. The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is seen. Shifting fluid is seen.
The image below shows a fundus which reveals retinal detachment inferiorly from 3-9 o'clock with tear at 3:30.

Solution to Question 29:
Sulphur hexafluoride is the gas used in pneumatic retinopexy for the treatment of retinal detachments
Pneumatic retinopexy is used for the treatment of fresh retinal detachments with a single retinal break in the superior two-thirds of the fundus. In this procedure, a bubble is injected intravitreally through the conjunctiva and postoperatively the patient is positioned so that the bubble tamponades the retinal break against the retinal pigment epithelium.

Solution to Question 30:
Exudative retinal detachment is characterized by positive shifting fluid sign. Among her conditions, toxemia of pregnancy is one of the causes of exudative retinal detachment.
Exudative retinal detachment occurs due to the presence of subretinal fluid in the absence of tear or traction. It is caused by:
Malignant melanoma of the choroid
Retinoblastoma
Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada (VKH) syndrome
Uveal effusion syndrome
Posterior scleritis
Coat’s disease
Malignant hypertension
Pregnancy-induced hypertensive retinopathy
Sympathetic ophthalmitis
Patients present with sudden and painless diminution of vision, visual field defects and grey reflex
(detached retina looks grey). Indirect ophthalmoscopy is the investigation of choice.
The image depicts retinal detachment showing a smooth, detached convex retina with subretinal fluid.

Solution to Question 31:
The presence of shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.
In serous retinal detachment, there is a subretinal accumulation of the serous fluid mostly due to the breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier. When the position of the head is altered, the fluid shifts to the dependent portion. Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration. A retinal tear or preretinal traction is absent.
Other options:
Option B: Traction RD has a concave configuration and breaks are absent. Retinal mobility is severely reduced and shifting fluid is absent.
Option C: Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous with substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells. Retinal breaks are also seen.
Solution to Question 32:
Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAO).
They are cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. They originate from atherosclerotis plaques in larger arteries. The image below shows Hollenhorst plaques (arrow).

Solution to Question 33:
The above image shows a loss of foveal reflex and central serous retinopathy, therefore showing focal foveal detachment.
There is oedema at the fovea signifying foveal detachment from underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Macular oedema is also present (grey dull retina with a ring reflex around the site of oedema). Thus, the most appropriate choice would be foveal detachment.
Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region. It occurs due to increased permeability of choriocapillaris, leading to fluid accumulation in the subretinal space. Therefore, it is now known as central
serous choriopathy (CSC).
If there is serous retinal detachment at macula, there is sudden painless loss of vision. Patients also have relative positive scotoma, micropsia and metamorphopsia. On ophthalmoscopy, a circular ring reflex present. The foveal reflex is absent. On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), an enlarging ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern is seen.
Treatment is generally not required. It is usually self-limiting, but often recurrent. Steroids are contraindicated.

Solution to Question 34:
The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Smokestack appearance is another pattern of fundus seen in CSR and is a characteristic sign of this condition.
Amsler grid is used for:
Assess macular function and detecting maculopathy.
Evaluate the visual field of 10°
Good for follow-up in CSR

ETDRS stands for Early Treatment for Diabetic Retinopathy Study.
ETDRS was a clinical trial designed to evaluate if argon laser photocoagulation or aspirin treatment can reduce the risk of visual loss or slow the progression of diabetic retinopathy in patients with mild-to-severe nonproliferative or early proliferative diabetic retinopathy. During the study, three new visual acuity charts were created in place of Snellen's visual chart.
Macular disorders, Retinal dystrophies, and Vitreal disorders

Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario with a characteristic smoke stack pattern on FFA is suggestive of a diagnosis of central serous retinopathy. In CSR, the outer blood-retinal barrier is disrupted.
CSR is the serous detachment of the neurosensory retina with focal and multifocal areas of leakage at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), mainly affecting the macular area. That is why the patient who is usually a young male presents with macular symptoms such as blurring of central vision, metamorphopsia.
The blood-retina barrier (BRB) is composed of inner and outer barriers. The outer BRB refers to the barrier formed at the retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cell layer and regulates the movement of solutes and nutrients from the choroid to the sub-retinal space. By contrast, the inner BRB, similar to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is located in the inner retinal microvasculature and comprises the microvascular endothelium, which lines these vessels.

Assess macular function

Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) ARMD is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. Initially characterized by macular Drusens, which later progress to geographical atrophy. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry ARMD. Wet (exudative, neovascular) ARMD is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.

The image is that of fluorescein angiography showing the "flower petal pattern," which is seen in cystoid macular edema (CME). The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer at the macula
The accumulation of fluid in the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer leads to retinal thickening at macula and loss of foveal depression, formation of cystic spaces (honey-comb macula). Risk factors include retinitis pigmentosa, uveitis, niacin, PGE2 analogues, epinephrine in aphakia, diabetic retinopathy, retinal venous occlusion and Irvin-Gass syndrome (CME
post-cataract surgery).
Symptoms may include blurring of vision, distortion, and micropsia.
Therapeutic approaches for treating CME depend on the underlying etiology. This includes steroids, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, anti-VEGF agents, PPV for associated vitreomacular traction.

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.
Maculopathy is common in eyes developing hypotony, which is defined as IOP <6 mmHg. The most common cause is excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery (Option D). Other causes include trauma such as cyclodialysis of the uvea (Option B), penetrating injury (Option C), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment, and other systemic causes such as dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, uremia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents. They usually cause bilateral hypotonic maculopathy.
Suprachoroidal hemorrhage is a bleed into the suprachoroidal space that results from the rupture of the posterior ciliary artery. When the bleed is severe it causes extrusion of intraocular contents that is termed as expulsive hemorrhage. It is a rare but dreaded complication of the phacoemulsification procedure. Signs seen in suprachoroidal hemorrhage are:
Progressive increase in intraocular pressure
Prolapse of iris
Loss or partial obscuration of the red reflex
In severe cases there can be extrusion of the posterior segment contents into the anterior chamber and through the incision such as vitreous extrusion
Immediate treatment involves rapid closure of the incision followed by administration of
IOP-lowering medications such as oral acetazolamide and topical or systemic steroids to reduce inflammation. Standard post-operative antibiotics can be added in these patients.

Other causes of Bull’s eye maculopathy include chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, congenital cone dystrophy, juvenile X-linked retinoschisis, and juvenile Batten's disease.
Fundus autofluorescence is a non-invasive imaging modality. It reflects the morphological changes associated with the metabolism of lipofuscin and does not require the injection of any fluorescent dye.

"a" wave in an electroretinogram (ERG) represents rods and cones.
Electroretinography is used to evaluate retinal functions by examining the electrical response to a light stimulus.
Electroretinograms (ERGs) show the amplitudes of currents that flow within the eye following exposure to a point of light. The amplitudes are analyzed into waves, which are composed of the responses of neuronal, glial, and retinal pigment epithelial cells.
ERG:
The a-wave originates from photoreceptors (rods and cones)
The b-wave originates from Muller and bipolar cells, but is directly dependant on photoreceptors
The c-wave originates from retinal pigment epithelial cells and retinal glial cells
Oscillatory potentials (OPs) originate in the inner retina
Scotopic ERGs are used to evaluate responses starting from rod photoreceptors exposed to flash-light in darkness, and photopic ERGs are used to evaluate responses starting from cone photoreceptors exposed to flash-light under constant light exposure.

An EOG measures the standing potential of the eye. It reflects the activity of the RPE and the photoreceptors. This means that an eye blinded by disease proximal to the photoreceptors will have a normal EOG. Arden ratio is the ratio between the light peak and the dark trough in an EOG.
The normal Arden ratio is 1.85 and above. A flat EOG occurs when the Arden ratio is less than 1.25.

Best's disease/Vitelliform macular dystrophy is an inherited macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula causing progressive central vision loss. It is
autosomal-dominant and linked to the mutation in the bestrophin (VMD2) gene. It is characterized by bilateral yellow, yolk-like (vitelliform) macular lesions.
The stages of evolution of the macular lesions are described as progressing from:
Pre-vitelliform stage
Vitelliform stage - scrambled egg stage with or without hypopyon
Vitelliruptive - the lesion breaks and visual acuity drops
The atrophic stage
Patients with Best’s disease usually have good visual acuity when the "yolk" remains intact.

Solution to Question 20:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario is Stargardt's disease.
Stargardt's disease also known as Stargardt macular dystrophy or fundus flavimaculatus is the most common macular dystrophy. It most commonly is inherited in an autosomal-recessive manner caused by a mutation on an adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette (ABCA4) gene.
Characterized by macular "pisciform" flecks that accumulate at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), sometimes resulting in central macular atrophy early in life. Patients develop a macula with a “beaten bronze” appearance caused by atrophic changes in the RPE. In addition, a "dark" or "silent" choroid is seen on the fluorescein angiography that appears as a prominent retinal circulation against hypofluorescent choroid.
The electroretinogram (ERG) and electro-oculography (EOG) are normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases. Of note, the ERG findings do not directly correlate with clinical findings.
There is no known proven treatment for this disease. Because ABCA4 plays a role in vitamin A processing in the visual cycle, additional vitamin A is suspected to make the disease worse.

The image below shows macular pisciform flecks.

Other options:
Option A: Retinitis pigmentosa: abnormal electroretinogram (ERG).
Option B: Rod–cone dystrophy: abnormal ERG.
Option D: Best's disease: Normal ERG with abnormal electrooculogram (EOG).
Solution to Question 21:
Silent/Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease. The classic feature of 'silent choroid' is due to the masking of background choroidal fluorescence by lipofuscin deposits in the subretinal space.
Stargardt disease constitutes the most common type of macular dystrophy. It has mutations in a photoreceptor cell-specific ATP-binding cassette gene (ABC4) that is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The disease usually starts in the juvenile group with progressive central vision loss and color vision loss that occurs due to the atrophy of the macular retinal pigment epithelium with an accumulation of discrete pisciform flecks of lipofuscin.
Signs of Stargardt’s disease:
Beaten bronze appearance of the macula that is caused by the atrophic changes in the RPE.
Silent/Dark choroid on FFA.
Visual field testing shows central vision loss.
The electroretinogram (ERG) is normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases.
Fundus flavimaculatus is genetically considered to be a part of the same spectrum as Stargardt's disease with late onset i.e. usually after 40 years of age.

Other options:
Option B: Best's disease also known as vitelliform macular dystrophy is an autosomal dominant macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula, causing progressive central vision loss. This disease is linked to mutations in the bestrophin (VMD2) gene and they do not exhibit silent choroid on FFA. Findings seen in Best’s disease are:
Vitelliform(yolk like) appearance of the fundus
Relatively normal ERG results associated with abnormal EOG
The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula.

Option C: Age related Macular degeneration(ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs. ARMD is classified as dry and wet ARMD where the hallmarks are the presence of drusen and choroidal neovascularization respectively. Drusen are extracellular eosinophilic deposits between RPE and Bruch’s membrane.
Clinical features include loss of central vision, distorted vision (lines seen as wavy), and sudden painless loss of vision as seen in wet ARMD. The image below shows Drusens in the macular area in dry macular degeneration.
Option D: Cystoid Macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in the blood-retinal barrier. In CME on fundoscopy, a honeycomb appearance and on FFA flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image shows the flower petal pattern on FFA as seen in CME.

Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is associated with Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).
PHPV is a developmental disorder of the vitreous humor. In this condition, there is persistence of the embryonic hyaloid vessel.
Anterior PHPV - Here, the remnant vessel is attached to the back of the lens but does not reach the optic nerve.
Posterior PHPV- In this form of the disease, the vessel arises from the optic nerve.
Clinically, PHPV presents with leucocoria and microphthalmia, and there can be complications such as tractional retinal detachments.
This condition has a poor prognosis regardless of the time of intervention.

When compared to blood, vitreous humor has a high concentration of ascorbate. The vitreous: plasma ratio of ascorbic acid concentration is 9:1.
This high concentration of ascorbic acid is maintained by the active transport by the ciliary body epithelium, and it is attributed to the ability of the ascorbate to absorb ultraviolet rays and act as a free radical scavenger.

These are synchysis scintillans, which are floaters composed of cholesterol bodies, found in the vitreous (extending into the anterior chamber in this picture).
Synchysis scintillans are vitreous opacities that occur as a consequence of chronic vitreous haemorrhage, often in a blind eye. This condition is usually discovered, when frank haemorrhage is no longer present. They are composed of cholesterol derived from plasma cells or degraded products of erythrocytes.
Vitreous opacities can be caused by a variety of pathological processes and the following are few examples of vitreous opacities:
Vitreous haemorrhage
Asteroid hyalosis
Synchysis scintillans
Amyloidosis
Vitreous cyst
Persistent fetal vasculature.
Solution to Question 25:
The examination findings are suggestive of asteroid bodies/hyalosis. It is not common in myopes.
Asteroid hyalosis is a common degenerative process in which calcium pyrophosphate particles collect within the vitreous gel. It is seen clinically as numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities of varying size and density. These move with the vitreous during eye movements but do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile.
Only one eye is affected in 75% of patients; it rarely causes visual problems and the majority of patients are asymptomatic. The cause of asteroid hyalosis is unknown, but it has been associated with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The prevalence of
asteroid hyalosis increases with age and affects 3% of those aged 75–86 years. It is more common in men than in women. While treatment of asteroid hyalosis is usually unnecessary, vitrectomy may occasionally be indicated.

Visual prognosis is good in the majority of cases. It is an important cause of visual morbidity in young males from the Indian subcontinent.

Solution to Question 1:
The lens of the eye originates embryonically from the surface ectoderm.
Surface ectoderm gives rise to lens, conjunctival and corneal epithelium and epithelial lining of lacrimal glands and tarsal glands.
Solution to Question 2:
The youngest fibers of the lens are the peripheral part, the cortex. The nucleus of the lens is the central part containing the oldest fibers.
The lens fibers are produced by mitosis of the epithelial cells in the pre-equatorial zone. As the lens fibers elongate and the new ones are formed, the older ones are pushed towards the depth of the lens so that the youngest fibers are the most superficially located.

Solution to Question 3:

The image shows bilateral cataracts in the Y-shaped sutures of the lens. These are very slowly progressive congenital cataracts and do not require any surgical intervention.

Embryonic nucleus: Innermost nucleus formed at around 1–3 months of gestation
Fetal nucleus: From 3 months of gestation till birth
Infantile nucleus: From birth to puberty
Adult nucleus
As lens fibers grow anteriorly and posteriorly, a pattern emerges where the ends of the fibers meet. These patterns of cell association are known as sutures.
Y-shaped sutures are recognizable at about 8 weeks of gestation.

The hyaloideo-capsular ligament of Weigert is the attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens.
It is the annular region (1–2 mm in width and 8–9 mm in diameter) where the vitreous is attached to the posterior aspect of the lens.
Erggelet’s or Berger’s space is at the centre of the hyaloideo-capsular ligament, a potential space between the vitreous and the lens. The canal of Cloquet arises from this space and courses posteriorly through the central vitreous, which is the former site of the hyaloid artery in the embryonic vitreous.
Posteriorly, Cloquet’s canal opens into a funnel-shaped region anterior to the optic disc, whch is known as the area of Martegiani.

The crystalline lens derives its nutrition from the aqueous humor.
The lens is an avascular structure. It receives nutrition mostly from the aqueous humor and, to some extent, from the vitreous humor as well. Glucose is the main energy source. Major intrinsic protein 26 (MIP 26)/Aquaporin 0 in the lens is responsible for maintaining transparency by transporting water and glycerol across the lens.

The lens epithelium is a single layer of cells on the anterior surface of the lens. Solution to Question 8:
Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced, functional state by glutathione.
Glutathione is present in high concentrations in the lens, particularly in the epithelial layer. One of its key functions is to maintain protein thiols in their reduced state, which preserves the lens transparency by preventing the formation of high molecular weight crystalline aggregates and protects the lens from oxidative stress.
The lens is highly prone to photochemical reactions from continuous exposure to ultraviolet rays (295–400 nm), leading to reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation. Its defence relies heavily on superoxide dismutase, ascorbate, catalase and glutathione peroxidase.
With ageing or cataracts, levels of glutathione and ascorbic acid (in reduced form) significantly decrease.

Solution to Question 20:
The inability to see objects in bright light is not a feature of cuneiform cataract, as the lens opacity is peripheral, allowing visibility in bright light during miosis.
The loss of the ability to see objects in bright light is a feature of posterior subcapsular cataract (visually handicapping), cupuliform cataract and nuclear cataract as these present with central opacities.
When a person is exposed to bright light, the pupil undergoes miosis (constriction). These central opacities come to lie directly in the path of axial rays, allowing no transmission of rays. Therefore, there is an inability to see objects in bright light. However, in dim light, when there is mydriasis (dilatation of the pupil), some rays may pass around the opacity, leading to an improvement in dim-light vision.
Furthermore, the complicated cataract, steroid-induced cataract, radiation-induced mainly present with a posterior subcapsular cataract and therefore have a similar clinical picture.

Solution to Question 1:
The child should be operated at 4-6 weeks of age.
When a child has unilateral or bilateral cataract impairing vision (involving the visual axis), the cataract surgery must be performed before 2-4 months of age. This is because 2-4 months is the critical period for visual maturation and development of the fixation reflex in children. A unilateral cataract is more dangerous than a bilateral cataract because the risk of amblyopia is greater. Under-correction of intraocular lens (IOL) power is needed in children.
In children < 2 years of age:
In unilateral cases, primary implantation is indicated as soon as the patient is fit for anesthesia, ideally between 2 and 3 months of age. The power is undercorrected by 20%.
The earlier the surgery is done, the better the chance that deep amblyopia can be overcome.
After the cataract has been aspirated, an elective posterior capsulectomy–anterior vitrectomy is performed. The posterior chamber IOL is inserted through a scleral tunnel, which is prepared in advance.
Sulcus implantation is indicated in neonates and infants less than 1 year of age. In children between 2 and 8 years of age:
An IOL is implanted but power is undercorrected by 10%.
An in-the-bag IOL is chosen for children above 1 year of age because they are less likely to need an IOL exchange.
Beyond 8 years, IOL power is the same as the calculated value.
Solution to Question 2:
The self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made in small-incision cataract surgery (SICS).
SICS is a type of extracapsular cataract extraction techniques (ECCE). In these techniques,
the major portion of the anterior capsule with the epithelium, nucleus, and cortex are removed, leaving behind the intact posterior capsule.
Note: Newer cataract surgeries include femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS), micro-incision cataract surgery (MICS) and Phaconit. FLACS is a microincision cataract surgery or a micro-phacoemulsification where a femtosecond laser is used to make the corneal incisions, perform capsulorhexis and fragment the lens. MICS refers to the phacoemulsification techniques that can be performed through a microincision (<2 mm). Phaconit is the term for the bimanual micro-phacoemulsification done with the needle incision technique through an incision of <1mm.
Solution to Question 3:
At present, the only indication of intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is markedly subluxated and dislocated lens.
In ICCE, the entire cataractous lens along with the intact capsule is removed by rupturing the zonules. Therefore, weak and degenerated zonules are a prerequisite for this method. Methods of
lens delivery include cryoextraction (best method), forceps extraction (Arruga forceps), wire vectis method and Indian Smith method. ICCE is no longer used for cataract treatment due to the large incision required, inability to implant an IOL and a high rate of complications like vitreous loss, retinal detachment and cystoid macular edema.
Solution to Question 4:
The length of the incision in phacoemulsification varies from 1.5 to 2.4 mm. The option closest to this answer is B, i.e., 2 to 2.5 mm.
In phacoemulsification, the nucleus of the lens is emulsified and aspired. This is done by the phacoemulsifier. It acts through a hollow 1-mm titanium needle, which vibrates by at an ultrasonic speed of 40000 times a second. The steps of phacoemulsification are given below:
Step 1 - Small clear corneal incision
Step 2 - Continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis
Step 3 - Hydro dissection
Step 4 - Hydro delineation is done in some cases.
Steps 5 and 6 - Emulsification and aspiration of the nucleus
Step 7 - Removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration technique
Step 8 - Implantation of a foldable lens
Length of the incision in various cataract surgeries:
Phacoemulsification- 1.5–2.4 mm.
Micro-phacoemulsification- 1–1.5 mm.
Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE)- 12–14 mm.
Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE)- 8–12 mm.
Solution to Question 5:
The most common late complication following cataract surgery is posterior capsule opacification.
Posterior capsule opacification, known as after or secondary cataract, is the most common late postoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation of left out anterior epithelial cells.

Solution to Question 6:
The most important factor in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis is preoperative preparation with povidone-iodine.
Postoperative endophthalmitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis. Flora of the eyelids and conjunctiva are the most frequent source. Other potential sources include contaminated solutions and instruments, environmental air, and the surgeon and other operating room personnel.
Prophylaxis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes:
Instillation of 5% povidone-iodine into the conjunctival fornices and leaving this undisturbed for at least 3 minutes prior to surgery. This is the most important factor.
Scrupulous preparation of the surgical site
Treatment of pre-existing infections such as blepharitis
Antibiotic prophylaxis
Intracameral cefuroxime (1 mg in 0.1 mL) injected into the anterior chamber (AC) at the end of surgery.
Post-operative subconjunctival injection can achieve bactericidal levels in the AC for at least 1–2 hours.
Preoperative topical fluoroquinolone antibiotics are frequently given in regimens from 1 hour t 3 days before surgery
Patients present with ocular pain, diminished vision, circumciliary congestion and hypopyon. The differential diagnosis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes retained lens material in the AC, vitreous hemorrhage, postoperative uveitis and toxic reaction to the use of inappropriate or contaminated irrigating fluid or viscoelastic.
Solution to Question 7:
A post cataract surgery patient presenting within 36 hours of surgery with inflammation, congestion and hypopyon as seen in the image, is suggestive of acute bacterial endophthalmitis. The treatment of acute bacterial endophthalmitis is intravitreal antibiotics.
Endophthalmitis is an intraocular inflammation affecting the inner structures of the eyeball. Acute postoperative bacterial endophthalmitis occurs within 1-7 days after cataract surgery and the most important factor to prevent it is preoperative administration of 5% povidone iodine. The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid, and a decrease in vision. The patient classically shows inflammation of the eye, corneal edema and a hypopyon due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.
Once the endophthalmitis sets in it is important to treat all the cases empirically with a combination of antibiotics and steroids from the beginning. The various drugs, routes and surgical management used to treat endophthalmitis are as follows:
The mainstay of treatment is intravitreal injections of antibiotics.
First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus ceftazidime 2.25mg in 0.1ml.
Second choice:Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus amikacin 0.4mg in 0.1ml.
If there is no improvement, a repeat intravitreal injection should be given after 48 hours
Topical antibiotics are started immediately and used frequently.
Vancomycin (50mg/ml) or cefazolin (50mg/ml)
Amikacin (20mg/ml) or tobramycin
Systemic antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment but are commonly used in practice.
Steroid therapy includes:
Intravitreal injection of dexamethasone (0.4mg in 0.1ml) which is started along with antibiotics.
Topical dexamethasone (0.1%)
Oral steroids such as prednisolone are started after 24 hours of intensive antibiotic therapy.
Supportive therapy includes:
Cycloplegics such as atropine 1%
Anti-glaucoma drugs such as oral acetazolamide or timolol in patients with raised intraocular pressure
Pars plana vitrectomy is done if the patient does not improve with the above therapy in 48-72 hours or when the visual acuity is reduced to hand movements near the eye
Other options:
Option A: Steroids are given in endophthalmitis to reduce the inflammation of the tissues. The preferred route of administration is either by intravitreal injections, topical concentrations or oral route. Intravenous route (option A) of administration of steroids is not used in endophthalmitis.
Option B: Systemic administration (intravenous) of antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment but are commonly used in practice as an add on.

Diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery, supported with the image of vacoulated clusters seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig’s pearls. It is a type of after cataract.
After cataract, or secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification, is a late postoperative complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It is the most common late postoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation of left out anterior epithelial cells. Different types of after cataract include:
Elschnig’s pearls: The subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soap bubble like clusters along the posterior capsule.
Soemmering’s ring: A peripheral dense ring is formed behind the iris and is enclosed between layers of the capsule.
Dense membranous after-cataract: It is formed in the pupillary area impairing the vision.
Thin membranous after-cataract: It is thickened posterior capsule.

Treatment of after cataract is by Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy of the posterior capsule, which works on the principle of photodisruption, or surgical posterior capsulotomy.
Option B: Irvine–Gass syndrome is cystoid macular edema (CME) that develops in post-cataract surgery patients. Though it is mostly clinically insignificant, some cases can present with blurring of vision, one to three months after surgery. In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearance and on fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image depicts the flower petal pattern seen on FFA.

Option C: Post operative endophthalmitis presents as ocular pain, diminished vision and hypopyon within months to years after the surgery. Fungal endophthalmitis can rarely occur with puff ball exudates in the vitreous cavity.
Option D: UGH syndrome is where uveitis, glaucoma and hyphema occurs simultaneously. It is seen commonly with rigid anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.
