Glaucomatocyclitic crisis/Posner–Schlossman Syndrome [PSS]) describes recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) associated with mild anterior uveitis. The mechanism is thought to be acute trabeculitis, and there is evidence that infection, possibly cytomegalovirus (CMV) or Helicobacter pylori, may play a role. PSS typically affects young to middle-aged adults. Males are affected more frequently than females.
Signs:
Slit-lamp biomicroscopy typically shows a few anterior chamber cells and one to several fine white central keratic precipitates.
Mydriasis is common; posterior synechiae are not a feature.

Gonioscopy shows an open-angle.
Treatment:
Topical steroids are used to control inflammation, with aqueous suppressants to lower the IOP.
Topical or oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents may also be beneficial.
Note: In PSS, the rise in IOP is out of proportion to the pain felt. There is often a mild discomfort and pain may even be absent.

Forward flow of the aqueous is blocked as tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against the lens/intraocular lens (IOL)/anterior hyaloid of the vitreous. Solution to Question 1:
The ciliary body derives its blood supply from the long posterior ciliary artery and anterior ciliary arteries, which form the major arterial circle at the root of the iris.
The ciliary body is a triangular structure that begins at the base of the iris and becomes continuous with the choroid at the ora serrata. It is approximately 6–6.5 mm in an anteroposterior dimension.
It consists of an anterior portion called the pars plicata and a posterior portion called the pars plana (option A). The pars plicata contains approximately 70 finger-like projections called ciliary processes, which are covered by the ciliary body epithelium. These processes secrete aqueous humor (option C). The pars plana is the flat part of the ciliary body and ends at the ora serrata.
The smooth muscle of the ciliary body is divided into three groups of fibers:
Outer longitudinal portion that attaches anteriorly to the scleral spur and trabecular meshwork fibers
Middle oblique portion
Inner circular portion (responsible for accommodation) (option B)

Solution to Question 2:
The image shows corectopia, an abnormal eccentrically placed pupil.
It can be a congenital anomaly or an acquired defect with essential iris atrophy. It may be associated with high myopia or ectopia lentis, among other conditions.
Solution to Question 3:
A D-shaped pupil is seen in iridodialysis.
Iridodialysis is the dis-insertion of the iris root from the ciliary body attachment. It may occur following ocular trauma. A red reflex can be obtained from the peripheral gap in the iris.
The given image depicts iridodialysis and a D-shaped pupil.

Solution to Question 4:
The pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis is keratic precipitates (KP).
Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits at the back of cornea. The composition of KPs varies with the type of uveitis.
Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis:
Corneal signs
Corneal edema
Keratic precipitates (Pathognomonic)
Posterior corneal opacity
Anterior chamber signs
Aqueous cells
Aqueous flare (earliest sign)
Hypopyon
Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae
Iris signs
Loss of normal pattern
Change in color
Iris nodules (Koeppe, Busacca)
Posterior synechiae
Neovascularization
Pupillary signs
Constricted pupi
Irregular pupil shape
Ectropion of pupillary margin
Occlusion pupillae

Solution to Question 5:
Aqueous flare is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis.
Aqueous flare is due to the leakage of protein particles into the aqueous humor from damaged blood vessels. It is demonstrated on the slit-lamp examination. It is based on the principle
of Brownian movement or Tyndall phenomenon.
Aqueous flare is usually marked in non-granulomatous uveitis and minimal in granulomatous uveitis. The presence of cells in the anterior chamber denotes an active inflammatory process.
The image below is a high magnification slit-beam photograph 3×1 mm in size in a darkroom showing the presence of cells and flare.

Solution to Question 6:
Eye pain, photophobia and red-eye along with the slit lamp finding of keratic precipitates suggests a diagnosis of acute anterior uveitis. Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular
deposits occurring at the back of the corneal endothelium.
Keratuc precipitates are arranged in a triangular fashion, occupying the center and inferior parts of the cornea (Arlt's triangle).
Solution to Question 7:
The pupil in acute anterior uveitis is constricted (pupillary sphincter spasm), irregular and sluggishly reactive to light
In an acute attack of uveitis, the pupil is irregular and narrow due to irritation of sphinchter pupillae. Pupillary signs in chronic anterior uveitis is as follows:
Festooned pupil results from the application of mydriatics in segmental posterior synechiae.
Occlusio pupillae results when the pupil is completely occluded due to the organization of the exudates across the pupillary area.
Seclusio pupillae due to ring synechiae, that prevent the circulation of aqueous humor from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber.
The image below shows a festooned pupil.

Solution to Question 8:
Koeppe's nodules and Bussaca's nodules develop on the iris in granulomatous uveitis.
Granulomatous uveitis is a chronic proliferative inflammation seen in reponse to tuberculosis, leprosy, syphilis and sarcoidosis. Infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, with proliferation of mononuclear cells leads to the formation of iris nodule. Koeppe's nodules are seen at
the pupillary margin. Bussaca's nodules are seen on the peripheral part of the anterior surface of iris.

Solution to Question 9:
Iris bombe formation is due to the development of annular or ring synechiae.
Annular posterior/ring synechiae are 360° adhesions of the pupillary margin to the anterior capsule of the lens. They prevent the circulation of aqueous humor from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber (seclusio pupillae). Thus, the aqueous collects behind the iris and pushes it anteriorly leading to iris bombe. This is usually followed by a rise in intraocular pressure. The anterior chamber is funnel-shaped when ring synechiae are present.
The image below shows iris bombe on slit lamp examination.


Solution to Question 10:
Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a type of non-granulomatous uveitis.
Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidious progressive anterior uveitis. It is mostly unilateral and associated with early cataract formation. Stellate keratic precipitates are seen and there is a notable absence of posterior synechiae.
Causes for chronic granulomatous uveitis include sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, herpes simplex, herpes zoster, syphilis, leprosy, brucellosis and phacoanaphylactic.
Solution to Question 11:
Intermediate uveitis refers to pars planitis. It involves inflammation of the pars plana.
The uvea consists of the iris, ciliary body and choroid. Inflammation of uveal tissue is called uveitis. It can be classified anatomically as follows:
Anterior uveitis: Inflammation of iris and pars plicata, consisting of iritis, iridocyclitis and anterior cyclitis
Intermediate uveitis: Inflammation of pars plana (pars planitis)
Posterior uveitis: Inflammation of the retina with or without involvement of the retina. It includes choroiditis, chorioretinitis, retinochoroiditis and neuroretinitis.
Panuveitis
Pathological classification divides uveitis into suppurative and nonsuppurative uveitis. Nonsuppurative uveitis is further classified into nongranulomatous and granulomatous uveitis.
The image is a schematic representation of the anatomical classification of uveitis.

Solution to Question 12:
Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis.
Snow banking refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without peripheral retinal periphlebitis.
Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation of the pars plana and presents with retrolental flare, few keratic precipitates, vitreous cells and snow-ball opacities (Ant’s egg opacities). These are typical exudates present near the ora serrata in the inferior quadrant.
Treatment of intermediate uveitis is by the Kaplan 4-step protocol:
Periocular steroid: Sub tenon injection of triamcinolone acetate
Systemic steroid
Cryotherapy over snow banking
Pars plana vitrectomy

Solution to Question 13:
ANA-positive oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is associated with the highest risk for iridocyclitis (uveitis).
A positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test result confers increased risk for uveitis in children with JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination. Uveitis in JIA is characteristically chronic,
non-granulomatous, and bilateral. It presents as a white eye without congestion- white uveitis. Complications include complicated cataracts, secondary glaucoma, and band-shaped keratopathy.
Note: Intraocular lens (IOL) implantation can be considered in most pediatric patients with well-controlled uveitis, but JIA-associated uveitis should be considered as a relative contraindication.
Solution to Question 14:
Amsler sign is seen in Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI).
Amsler sign is the hemorrhage caused by cataract surgery in FHI. During cataract surgery, fine filiform hemorrhages from the opposite angle are seen to occur as soon as the anterior chamber is opened. This is due to neovascularization.
Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidiously progressive, non- granulomatous anterior uveitis, that is usually unilateral. Stellate KPs are seen and tiny crystals (Russell bodies) may be present on the iris surface. There are no posterior synechiae. Rubeosis iridis may be present.

changes, fine white central keratic precipitates (KPs) and mydriasis. Treatment includes topical corticosteroids, cycloplegics, and aqueous suppressants.

Behcet's disease is a systemic vascular disease. It is associated with HLA B5 >> B51. Patients have obliterative vasculitis due to circulating immune complexes, leading to a recurrent, bilateral non-granulomatous uveitis. There is acute recurrent iridocyclitis, transient hypopyon, periphlebitis, retinitis, vitritis and cystoid macular edema (CME).
Solution to Question 18:
The clinical scenario of photophobia and blurring of vision along with red-eye and irregularly shaped pupil suggests a diagnosis of anterior uveitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of the treatment of uveitis.
Steroids are the drug of choice in anterior uveitis. They reduce inflammation by their
anti-inflammatory effect. Cycloplegics like 1% atropine relieve spasm of the iris sphincter and ciliary muscles. They prevent the formation of synechiae and reduce exudation. Systemic therapy includes steroids, NSAIDs, and immunosuppressants.
Immunosuppressants like voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor) are used in severe cases. They are being studied under a program called LUMINATE.

Solution to Question 1:
The image shows metamorphopsia seen in posterior uveitis.
Metamorphopsia is a condition in which patients perceive distorted images of the object. It is measured using the Amsler grid, which tests the central 10 degrees of vision. In posterior uveitis, metamorphopsia occurs due to macular edema.
Posterior uveitis is a painless inflammation of the choroid. Patients present with various visual symptoms like defective vision, black spots floating in front of the eye, micropsia/macropsia and positive scotomas.
Solution to Question 2:
Iris heterochromia is not a feature of Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome.
Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome is an idiopathic, multi-system disorder characterised by autoimmunity against melanocytes. It is associated with HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4 across different racial groups.
Patients may present with cutaneous, neurological and ocular features. Cutaneous features include alopecia, poliosis and vitiligo (option A). Neurological features include meningism, encephalopathy, tinnitus, deafness and vertigo (option B). Ocular features include bilateral chronic granulomatous panuveitis (option C), posterior uveitis, exudative retinal detachment, perilimbal vitiligo (Suguiura's sign) and sunset glow appearance of the fundus.
The modified diagnostic criteria for Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome are as follows:
Absence of a history of penetrating ocular trauma
Absence of other ocular disease entitie
Bilateral uveiti
Neurological and auditory manifestation
Integumentary findings, not preceding the onset of the central nervous system or ocular diseases, such as alopecia, poliosis, and vitiligo.
The treatment is high-dose (1–2 mg/kg/day) oral prednisolone, tapered over 3–6 months. This may be preceded by intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy (500–1000 mg/day).
Solution to Question 3:
Recurrent oral ulcers, ulcers over his scrotum with binocular pain and redness and a positive pathergy test point to a diagnosis of Behcet's disease. HLA B5 (HLA B51) is associated with Behcet's disease.
Behcet's disease is a systemic vasculitis that can cause recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, skin lesions and ocular inflammation. Pathergy test is usually positive. Ocular inflammation occurs in about 70% of patients and tends to be more severe in men. A classical presentation is relapsing/remitting acute onset panuveitis with retinal vasculitis which resolves spontaneously even without treatment. It is usually bilateral and non-granulomatous. Patients present with a transient mobile hypopyon in a relatively white eye. They may develop visual impairment if retinal vascular disease (vasculitis and occlusion) occurs.
Other options:
Option A: HLA-B27 is associated with Reiter's syndrome.
Option B: HLA DR1 and HLA-DR4 are associated with Vogt–Koyanagi–Haradas disease. Option D: HLA Bw54 is associated with Possner–Scholssman syndrome.
Note: The association between HLA-A29 and birdshot retinochoroidopathy is the most consistent of any medical disorder. Approximately 95% of patients with birdshot retinochoroidopathy are HLA-A29–positive.
Solution to Question 4:
The image shows the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) colonies on the
Lowenstein-Jensen medium. In tuberculosis (TB), granulomatous panuveitis is the most common
ocular feature.
Ocular TB commonly occurs due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB. It can have multiple presentations like lupus vulgaris of eyelid, tubercular conjunctivitis, interstitial keratitis, granulomatous uveitis and endophthalmitis. Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the MTB antigen.
Treatment of granulomatous panuveitis is anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) plus steroids.
Solution to Question 5:
Salt and pepper fundus is not seen in tuberculosis.
Salt and pepper fundus is seen when there are multiple small black and white spots present on the retina. It is also known as pseudo-retinitis pigmentosa. Its causes include congenital syphilis, rubella, Refsum’s disease, carriers of albinism, Leber’s congenital amaurosis and retinitis pigmentosa sine pigmentosa.

Solution to Question 6:
Dry, itchy eyes, blurred vision, sensitivity to light with candle wax dripping on fundus examination points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.
Sarcoidosis is a chronic granulomatous multi-system disease. Ocular inflammation occurs in 25–70% of sarcoid patients, which includes uveitis, conjuctival and lacrimal gland involvement. Chronic granulomatous panuveitis may be seen. Anterior uveitis is the most common manifestation.
In anterior uveitis due to sarcoidosis, "mutton fat" keratic precipitates (KPs) and/or small granulomatous KPs with iris nodules (Koeppe and/or Busacca) are seen. Trabecular meshwork (TM) nodules and/or tent-shaped peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) is also seen.
In intermediate uveitis, vitreous cells with snowbanking and snowball opacities/string of pearl appearance are seen. Posterior uveitis presents with candle-wax dripping (thick venous sheathing and periphlebitis), pre-retinal nodules (Lander’s sign), choroidal granulomata and sarcoid infiltration. Other ocular features seen are interstitial keratitis and band-shaped
keratopathy. Steroids are the mainstay of treatment in sarcoidosis.

Solution to Question 7:
Microangiopathy is the most common ocular feature of HIV infection.
Microangiopathy of the retina in HIV consists of the hemorrhages, micro-aneurysms and cotton-wool spots or soft exudates (axonal debris). Cotton wool spots are the most common finding of HIV retinopathy.
HIV leads to multiple opportunistic infections of the eye like cytomegalovirus (CMV) - most common cause of posterior uveitis in HIV - toxoplasmosis, Pneumocystis carinii and herpes zoster. These infections present as keratitis, choroiditis, retinitis and endophthalmitis.
The most common ocular adverse effect in patients receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is immune recovery uveitis (IRU). It is a non-granulomatous uveitis (usually anterior uveitis and vitritis) associated with a paradoxical or exaggerated reactivation of the immune system and an increase in intraocular inflammation. It occurs after receiving HAART for CMV chorioretinitis. Visual complications of IRU include cataract, cystoid macular edema (CME), glaucoma, and epiretinal membrane formation.
Solution to Question 8:
Painless blurring of vision in an HIV positive patient with "sauce and cheese" or "pizza pie" retinopathy (shown in the image) is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.
CMV retinitis is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in patients with HIV. It is often asymptomatic and can be classified as central or peripheral CMV retinitis. Central CMV retinitis is characterised by dense, white areas of retinal necrosis and retinal hemorrhage in the areas of necrosis - pizza pie or sauce and cheese appearance.
Peripheral CMV retinitis is less demarcated. The infection spreads along the vascular arcades in a brush fire-like fashion.
Solution to Question 9:
An HIV-positive patient with CD4+ count of 35/L presenting with decreased visual acuity, floaters and pizza pie retinitis (dense, white areas of retinal necrosis with interspersed areas of retinal hemorrhage) likely has CMV retinitis. The most rapid and accurate method to diagnose cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is viral nucleic acid detection in the intraocular fluid.
CMV retinitis is an opportunistic infection seen in HIV patients with a CD4+ count less than 50/L. Patients present with reduced vision due to macular involvement and floaters due to vitritis. One eye is usually affected initially. Retinitis is seen. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA), which is marked vascular sheathing that occurs in about 6% patients, may be seen. Cataract is common late-stage manifestation of CMV retinitis.
Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is a prodrug of ganciclovir that is taken orally. Ganciclovir slow-release intravitreal implant can also be used.

Solution to Question 10:
Monocular iritis, severe vitritis with a focal necrotic lesion on the macula is a classical description of ocular toxoplasmosis.
Ocular toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan. It causes severe recurrent attacks of posterior uveitis in adults, due to reactivation at previously inactive cyst-containing scars. A single inflammatory focus of fluffy white retinitis or retinochoroiditis associated with a pigmented scar ("satellite lesion") is typical. "Headlight in the fog" is the classic description of a white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through
vitritis. "Spill-over" anterior uveitis is common. Treatment:
Prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is given initially and tapered according to clinical response.
Pyrimethamine is administered as a loading dose of 75–100 mg for 1–2 days followed by 25–50 mg daily for 4 weeks in combination with oral folinic (not folic) acid 5 mg three times a week to
retard thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and folate deficiency.
Sulfadiazine 1 g four times daily for 3–4 weeks is usually given in combination with pyrimethamine.
Intravitreal therapy with clindamycin (1 mg) and dexamethasone (400 g) may be as effective a triple therapy in reactivated infection.
The image shows the characteristic "headlight in the fog" appearance:

Solution to Question 11:
The "headlight in fog" appearance is seen in toxoplasmosis.
Ocular toxoplasmosis presents with iridocyclitis, which can be granulomatous or
non-granulomatous. There is focal superficial necrotizing retinochoroiditis along with vitritis, which gives the "headlight in fog" appearance (image). Fundoscopy shows deep retinitis and papillitis with granulomas. Old choroid lesions of toxoplasmosis are punched-out lesions with pigmented borders.
The treatment of choice for ocular toxoplasmosis is triple therapy with systemic steroids, pyrimethamine, and sulfadiazine. Clindamycin is also used.

Solution to Question 12:
In acute retinal necrosis, the posterior pole is typically spared until late.
Acute retinal necrosis (ARN) occurs in immunocompetent individuals. It is a severe posterior uveitis causing retinal necrosis. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is the most common cause of acute retinal necrosis in adults. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) are the commonest causes of acute retinal necrosis in children.
Patients present with confluent peripheral necrotizing retinitis, retinal arteritis with
vaso-occlusion, and vitritis. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachments are common due to retinal thinning from large areas of necrosis. The posterior pole is involved only in the later stages.
Aciclovir is administered intravenously (10 mg/kg, every 8 hours) for 10–14 days, and then orally (800 mg, five times daily) for 6–12 weeks. Oral valaciclovir or famciclovir may be substituted for oral aciclovir, with similar outcomes but better tolerability. Intravitreal ganciclovir or foscarnet may enhance the prognosis. Systemic steroids may be started 24 hours after the initiation of antiviral therapy, especially in severe cases. Laser retinopexy is performed around necrotic areas.
Progressive outer retinal necrosis is a manifestation of HSV or varicella zoster virus (VZV) that occurs in immunocompromised individuals. It may begin at the posterior pole or the periphery. It has a rapid course and is not generally associated with vasculitis.
Solution to Question 13:
Painful decrease in vision following cataract surgery 6 months ago with granulomatous anterior uveitis, hypopyon, vitritis and a white plaque on the posterior lens capsule suggests a diagnosis of delayed-onset postoperative endophthalmitis caused by Propionibacterium acnes. The best management for the above clinical scenario would be vitrectomy and posterior capsulotomy, followed by intravitreal injection of vancomycin.
Delayed-onset endophthalmitis, a complication of cataract surgery, has a slow course and panuveitis like picture. There is low grade anterior chamber inflammation and vitritis. When caused by P. acnes, it typically presents from 3 months to 2 years after surgery with a characteristic white retro-lenticular plaque on the posterior capsule of lens. Endophthalmitis caused by Candida occurs within 3 months of surgery.
Management includes anterior vitrectomy, IOL explantation, posterior capsulectomy, intravitreal vancomycin, and a scleral-fixated intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.
Solution to Question 14:
Sympathetic ophthalmia is seen after a penetrating trauma.
Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating trauma or less frequently, following intraocular surgery, usually multiple vitreoretinal procedures.
Patients present between 2 weeks and 3 months after initial injury.
The earliest symptom is blurred near vision in the sympathizing (uninjured) eye. The earliest sign is a retrolental flare in the sympathizing eye. Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes. The fundus shows multifocal choroidal infiltrates in the mid-periphery. Sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen–Fuchs nodules (image)(a granuloma situated between Bruch membrane and the RPE) are also present.
Steroids are the basis of treatment. High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months. Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate can be used in resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents. Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury prevents the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

Solution to Question 15:
Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of post-traumatic endophthalmitis, followed by Bacillus cereus.
However, if the trauma involves soil contamination, Bacillus cereus is the most common cause of post-traumatic endophthalmitis.
Solution to Question 16:
Pilocarpine should not be used in cases of uveitis with raised intraocular pressure.
Hypertensive uveitis or inflammatory glaucoma occurs when uveitis is associated with raised IOP. It is treated with topical cycloplegics (atropine), topical steroids and IOP-lowering drugs like topical timolol or systemic acetazolamide. Pilocarpine is contraindicated since it causes miosis and ciliary spasm. It also increases intraocular inflammation.

Solution to Question 1:
Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.
Loss of eyebrows is seen in leprosy and myxedema.
Loss of eyelashes is seen in chronic blepharitis.

Other options:
Option A: Tylosis is a thickening of the tarsal border of the eyelid.
Option C: Trichiasis is an inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin.

Option D: Distichiasis is the presence of a double row of eyelashes.

Solution to Question 2:
The extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called distichiasis.
Distichiasis can occur due to congenital or acquired causes. These lashes may irritate the cornea. Management is by lid splitting with cryotherapy to the base of the hair follicles.
Other options:
Option A: Trichiasis is inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin. Option C: Tylosis is the thickening of the tarsal plate.
Option D: Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.
Solution to Question 3:
The given image shows an adhesion between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids, which suggests ankyloblepharon.
It may occur as a congenital anomaly or as acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, ulcers, or traumatic wounds of the lid margins. Treatment is the excision of the adhesions between lid margins. In severe cases where the adhesions involve the angle of the eyes, epithelial grafts can be used.
Other options:
Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva, whereby the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

Option C: Blepharophimosis is a congenital anomaly in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It appears contracted at the outer canthus.

Option D: Lagophthalmos is characterized by the inability to close the eyelids voluntarily. It may be due to a malfunction of the facial nerve. The image below shows nocturnal lagophthalmos (inability to close eyelids during sleep).

Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario and the above image is suggestive of trichiasis.
Trichiasis refers to the inward misdirection of cilia, which usually rub against the eyeball with the normal position of the lid margin. These patients present with foreign body sensations and photophobia. They experience troublesome irritation, pain, and lacrimation. On examination, one or more misdirected cilia touching the cornea are seen. The conjunctiva may be congested.
Treatment includes:
Epilation: Mechanical removal with forceps
Electrolysis: Method of destroying the lash follicle by electric current.
Cryoepilation
Surgical correction.

Telecanthus means an increased distance between medial canthi (widened root of the nose) with normal inter-pupillary distance.
In hypertelorism, there is a wide bony separation of the orbits.
In epicanthus, there are bilateral vertical folds of skin that extend from the upper or lower lids towards the medial canthi. They may give rise to pseudoesotropia.

Entropion refers to the inward rolling and rotation of the lid margin towards the globe. It is more common in the lower lid.
Causes include:

Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis during lid closure

Paralytic - caused by ipsilateral facial nerve palsy

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction most commonly caused by anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. The disorder is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles where the weakness increases during repeated use and may improve following rest.

Antibody testing - for Acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies, MuSK protein antibodies helps support a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

Solution to Question 1:
Moll glands are examples of apocrine sweat gland.
Moll glands are present in the eyelid. They are a type of modified apocrine sweat glands opening either into a lash follicle or directly onto the anterior lid margin between the lashes.

(adenocarcinoma of meibomian gland).
Recurrences of chalazia are not uncommon. However, the physician should entertain the possibility of malignancy in such cases and should biopsy a lesion that recurs or appears atypical. The pathologist should be alerted to the suspicion of sebaceous gland carcinoma and frozen sections and lipid stains should be requested.

Solution to Question 5:
The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long.
The lacrimal drainage system consists of the lacrimal sac, which is 10–12 mm long. It lies in the lacrimal fossa, between the anterior and posterior lacrimal crests. The lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.
The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and is directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is partially covered by a mucosal fold (valve of Hasner).
The puncta are openings on the lid margin. There are two canaliculi from the puncta. Each canaliculus (superior and inferior) has two parts: Vertical (2 mm) and horizontal (8 mm). The superior and inferior canaliculi usually unite to form the common canaliculus, which opens into the lateral wall of the lacrimal sac. A small flap of mucosa (Rosenmüller valve) overhangs the junction of the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac and prevents the reflux of tears into the canaliculi.

Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the eye characterised by loss of homeostasis of the tear film. Patients present with irritation, foreign body sensation and dryness. Tear film break-up test is used to determine the interval between a complete blink and appearance of first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. A drop of fluorescein is instilled in the eye, following by examination in the cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp.

Option C: Jones test is used in watering eye. It uses fluorescein dye.

Solution to Question 14:
Lacrimal pump failure can be confirmed with dacryoscintigraphy.
Lacrimal pump failure means an inability of the lid muscles to push tears towards the punctum for drainage. It is also called functional obstruction and may be secondary to lower lid laxity or orbicularis muscle weakness (eg. facial nerve palsy. It is confirmed by dacryoscintigraphy, in which a radioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac and its path visualised with an Anger gamma camera. An atonic lacrimal sac is seen.
Note: In cases of partial obstruction of the lacrimal apparatus, forced injection of fluid into the canalicular system (dacryocystography) can overcome the obstruction sites and point to a diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure. Thus, dacryoscintigraphy is better for the confirmation of lacrimal pump failure.
Solution to Question 15:
The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)
DCR involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. It re-establishes the lacrimal drainage and is hence the preferred surgery for chronic darcyocystectomy.
Chronic dacryocystitis is a long-standing inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Streptococcus hemolyticus and Staphylococcus aureus are the most common etiological agents. Initial treatment is with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory agents. Sequelae include lacrimal fistula formation and mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy. Treatment of lacrimal fistula is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR).
Solution to Question 16:
After dacryocystorhinostomy, the lacrimal sac drains into the middle meatus.
Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus.

Solution to Question 18:
Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is also the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.
Pleomorphic adenoma, or benign mixed tumor, presents commonly in middle age as a slowly progressive painless swelling in the upper outer quadrant of the eyelid. The bone is usually not invaded in these tumors. They are treated by surgical removal along with their intact
pseudo-capsule.
Malignant tumors of the lacrimal gland such as adenoid cystic carcinoma (option A), mucoepidermoid carcinoma (option C) and malignant mixed tumor (option D) generally occur in the elderly with a short history of appearance, rapid progression and pain. These tumors also present in the upper eyelid and are known to invade the adjacent bones. Radical surgical procedures and high dose radiotherapy are necessary for the removal of the tumor. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.
Both malignant and benign tumors are known to push the eyeball downwards and inwards while restricting the upwards and outwards movement of the eyeball.
The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:
Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA)
Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)
Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)

Non-surgical management

Solution to Question 19:
The surgery of choice for panophthalmitis is an evisceration. Evisceration gives a better cosmetic outlook after the surgery and is hence preferred. Enucleation is contraindicated in panophthalmitis due to the risk of meningitis through the exposed meningeal sheath of the optic
nerve stump. Some definitions:
Evisceration- removal of the contents of the eyeball, leaving behind the sclera. It is done in panophthalmitis.
Enucleation- removal of the eyeball, with the maximum part of the optic nerve. Extraocular muscles are left behind. The length of the optic nerve removed is 10 to 15 mm. Absolute indications for enucleation are retinoblastoma and malignant melanoma.
Exenteration- mutilating surgery in which all the contents of the orbits along with the periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball.
Debulking- reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays, debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.

The optic nerve passes through the optic canal and does not enter the cavernous sinus. Patients with orbital apex syndrome manifest complete ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, decreased corneal sensation, and vision loss. They usually develop optic nerve signs such as relative afferent pupillary defect. Proptosis is often present, but patients do not always complain of pain.

Tolosa–Hunt syndrome refers to idiopathic, nonspecific, granulomatous inflammation, involving the superior orbital fissure and/or orbital apex and/or cavernous sinus. It is a unilateral eye condition.
Clinically, it manifests as painful ophthalmoplegia and depending on the extent of involvement, it may present as superior orbital fissure syndrome or orbital apex syndrome.
Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by the following:
Pain, typically labeled as retro-orbital ache
Sensory loss/disturbances in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve
Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to the involvement of the 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve involvement
Ptosis, due to 3rd nerve paralysis
Orbital apex syndrome includes the following:
Features of superior orbital fissure syndrome described above
Features of optic nerve involvement, i.e., early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

The Hirschberg test gives a rough objective estimate of the angle of manifest strabismus. A pen torch is shone into the eyes from arm’s length, and the patient is asked to fixate on the light. The corneal reflection of the light will be (more or less) centered in the pupil of the fixating eye but will be decentred in a squinting eye, in the direction opposite to that of the deviation. The distance of the corneal light reflection from the center of the pupil is noted; each millimeter of the deviation is approximately equal to 7°.

Binocular single vision is tested by a synoptophore.
Binocular single vision is the state of simultaneous vision, which is achieved by the coordinated use of both eyes so that separate and slightly dissimilar images arising in each eye are appreciated as a single image by the process of fusion.
The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the presence of a manifest squint and is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 years), who generally find the test process enjoyable. It can also detect suppression.

In squint surgery, muscle resection leads to the strengthening of the muscle. The main types of procedure in squint surgery are as follows:
Weakening to decrease the effective strength of action of a muscle.
Recession slackens a muscle by moving it away from its insertion. It can be performed on any muscle except the superior oblique.
Disinsertion (or myectomy) involves detaching a muscle from its insertion without reattachment. It is most commonly used to weaken an overacting inferior oblique muscle.
Posterior fixation suture: The principle of this (Faden) procedure is to suture the muscle belly to the sclera posteriorly so as to decrease the pull of the muscle in its field of action without affecting the eye in the primary position.
Strengthening, to enhance the pull of a muscle.
Resection shortens a muscle to enhance its effective pull. It is suitable only for the rectus muscle.
Tucking of a muscle or its tendon is usually confined to the enhancement of the action of the superior oblique muscle.
Advancement of the muscle nearer to the limbus can be used to enhance the action of a previously recessed rectus muscle.
Vector adjustment procedures have the primary aim of altering the direction of muscle action.
Transposition refers to the relocation of one or more extraocular muscles to substitute for the action of an absent or severely deficient muscle. The most common indication is severe lateral ectus weakness due to acquired palsy of the 6th cranial nerve palsy.

The three-step test, also known as the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, is a diagnostic test used to identify which muscle is paralyzed in the case of an acquired hypertropia. This method uses the cover-uncover test, with or without the Maddox rod to measure the amount of deviation in different head positions.
The three-step test may also be used to diagnose the less common inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy. It is designed for the diagnosis of a single paretic vertical muscle and is unreliable when there are multiple paretic muscles or in restrictive strabismus. This test may also help in identifying if a superior rectus palsy is true or simulated in a patient with an inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist.
Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:
Step 1. Which eye is hypotrophic?
The eye hypotrophic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor.
Right superior rectus
Right inferior oblique
Left inferior rectus
Left superior oblique
Step 2.Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze? The hypotropia increases in right gaze.
Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us:
Left superior oblique
Right superior rectus
Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?
The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit.

Solution to Question 1:

Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pituitary apoplexy in pregnancy This acute onset event is almost always associated with compression at the level of optic chiasma causing heteronymous hemianopia (bitemporal hemianopia).
Pituitary apoplexy results from hemorrhagic infarction of a pre-existing pituitary adenoma or within a physiologically enlarged gland, which is well documented in pregnancy.
The nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma. Slow-growing microadenomas compress lower nasal optic fibers causing superior temporal quadrantanopia initially, before progressing to bitemporal hemianopia. However, an abrupt infarction or hemorrhage of a pre-existing pituitary adenoma will lead to rapid progression of the visual defect.
Heteronymous hemianopia is the loss of half of the visual field on different sides in both eyes. It is separated into two categories:
Binasal hemianopia – the loss of the fields surrounding the nose
Bitemporal hemianopia – the loss of the fields closest to the temples.
Common causes of bitemporal hemianopia due to central chiasmal lesions are as follows:
Suprasellar aneurysms
Tumors of the pituitary gland
Craniopharyngioma
Suprasellar meningioma
Glioma of the third ventricle

Solution to Question 3:
Central scotoma, paracentral scotoma and temporal field defects can be tested by monocular visual field testing with a red-headed neurological pin.
A patient who has central scotoma will either not see the pinhead in the centre of the field or perceive it black. This can be defined by moving the pin outwards in four different directions until the patient sees the pinhead as being red.
Placing the pin in each of the quadrants close to the centre and checking if the patient sees the red pinhead can detect a paracentral scotoma. This can also detect temporal field defects.
Solution to Question 4:
Congruous homonymous hemianopia is most suggestive of a lesion in the occipital cortex.
Homonymous hemianopia involves vision loss on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. This type of visual field loss is suggestive of a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma in the visual pathway.
Complete homonymous hemianopia involves the complete visual hemifields of both eyes and can occur with any large enough lesion posterior to the optic chiasma. Visual field examination alone cannot further localize the lesion in such cases.
Incomplete homonymous hemianopia is due to smaller lesions in the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasm. They are further divided into congruous and incongruous depending on the extent to which the defects in the two half fields match each other exactly.
Because of a relative disorder among axon bundles in the immediate post-chiasmal region, diseases in this location produce rather incongruent lesions.
More posteriorly, the axon bundles of the corresponding areas of the two hemifields are more closely aligned and hence, lesions of the occipital cortex produce congruous homonymous hemianopia while incongruous homonymous hemianopia is more likely seen with optic tract lesions.

(central) vision is spared.

Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cortical blindness with visual anosognosia (Anton syndrome). Since anterior visual pathways are not affected in cortical blindness, direct and consensual light reflexes are preserved.
Cortical blindness is usually associated with bilateral occipital infarcts where it is supplied by the posterior cerebral arteries and these infarcts usually involve both the primary visual cortex and visual association area. It is secondary to damage to the visual pathways posterior to the lateral geniculate nuclei; anterior visual pathways are intact. Visual field defects can vary depending on the extent and location of the infarct.
Direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes in cortical blindness as pupillary light reflex fibers exit the visual pathway at the level of the superior colliculus. They exit the optic tract before the lateral geniculate body (LGB) to reach the center for pupillary light reflex- pretectal nucleus at the midbrain.
Note: Anton syndrome is visual anosognosia (denial of loss of vision) associated with confabulation (defined as the emergence of memories of events and experiences which never took place) in the setting of obvious visual loss and cortical blindness.
Solution to Question 9:
The given scenario describes cilio-spinal reflex. Sympathetic fibers of cervical ganglion form the efferent limb of this reflex.
Cilio-spinal reflex:
Afferent inputs of this reflex are carried by the trigeminal nerve or cervical pain fibers (latera spinothalamic tract).
It synapses at the ciliospinal center of Budge, located at C8 to T2 in the intermediolateral (IML)
horn of the gray matter of the spinal cord.
The efferent branch of the reflex consists of:
Preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the upper thoracic and lower cervical spinal cord which goes to the cervical sympathetic chain and its three ganglia.
The postganglionic sympathetic fibers pass on the surface of the internal carotid artery and join the ophthalmic nerve at the cavernous sinus. Here, it passes through the nasociliary nerve to reach the ciliary body and innervates the dilator pupillae muscles, causing dilatation of the pupil.
This reflex is absent in Horner's syndrome and in lesions involving the cervical sympathetic fibers and it is enhanced in patients with cluster headache and barbiturate-induced coma.
Solution to Question 10:
The lateral geniculate body is not a part of the pupillary reflex pathway. It is part of the accommodation reflex and the visual pathway.
Pupillary light reflex pathway:
First neurons (sensory) connects each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the evel of the superior colliculi.
Second neurons (internuncial) connects each pretectal nucleus to both Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
Third neurons (preganglionic motor) connects the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion.
Fourth neurons (postganglionic motor) leaves the ciliary ganglion and passes in the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae.

Solution to Question 15:
Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is due to a lesion in the optic tract. The optic tracts contain both visual and pupillomotor fibers.
The visual fibers terminate in the lateral geniculate body, but the pupillary fibers leave the optic tract anterior to the lateral geniculate body, projecting through the brachium of the superior colliculus to terminate in the pretectal nuclei.
An optic tract lesion may, therefore, give rise to an afferent pupillary conduction defect.
Characteristically, the pupillary light reflex will be normal when the unaffected hemiretina is stimulated and absent, when the involved hemiretina is stimulated (i.e., light is shone from the hemianopic side).
Solution to Question 16:
Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve
damage. Marcus Gunn pupil also known as relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease as seen in optic nerve neuritis or primary open-angle glaucoma(POAG).
RAPD is caused due to a defect in the afferent pathway (optic nerve) of the pupillary light reflex in one eye.
It is diagnosed by the swinging flashlight test where the flashlight is swung to and fro, and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils constrict when any one eye is stimulated (due to direct and consensual light reflex). In the presence of RAPD, both
pupils will abnormally dilate when the affected eye is stimulated. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.
Causes of RAPD:
Optic nerve lesions (e.g.All types of optic neuritis, glaucoma)
Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)
Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
Maculopathy (macular degeneration )
Other options:
Option B: Adie tonic pupil is a unilateral dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor nerve supply damage. In these patients the light reflex is absent and the accomdation (near) reflex is sluggish. It is commonly seen in young
females and is associated with absent knee jerk.
Option C: Argyll Robertson pupils are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation. It is commonly seen in patients with neurosyphilis. In these patients the pupillary reflex is absent but the accommodation reflex is present (ARP).
Option D: Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.
Solution to Question 17:
Anisocoria greater in the light indicates the large pupil to be abnormal due to poor pupillary contraction from a parasympathetic abnormality. Among the given options, 1% pilocarpine and 0.1% pilocarpine can be used to differentiate fixed dilated pupil.
Mydriasis due to neurologic origin (3rd nerve palsy) responds readily to 1% pilocarpine, whereas there will be no response if the dilation is due to anticholinergic causes. Pupillary constriction
to 0.1% pilocarpine diagnoses Adie's pupil (due to denervation hypersensitivity). Application of 0.1% pilocarpine shows no response in other conditions or in the normal eye.
Example: A person presenting with dilated pupil following accidental application or inadvertent rubbing of atropine or antimuscarinic alkaloids from wild plants into the eye will not constrict in response to topical application of 1% Pilocarpine. But the patient showing dilation due to 3rd nerve palsy shows pupillary constriction in response to pupillary instillation of 1% pilocarpine.

The cell body of the second-order neuron in the sympathetic pathway for the pupil lies at the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8–T1).
The sympathetic pathway to the iris muscles consists of a chain of three neurons:
The first neuron arises from the hypothalamus along the brain stem to synapse in
the intermediolateral column of the spinal cord—the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8-T1).
From here (C8-T1), the second-order neuron arises. This joins the cervical sympathetic chain and synapses at the superior cervical ganglion.
The third-order neuron arises from the superior cervical ganglion and travels through the cavernous sinus along with the internal carotid artery.
Sympathetic fibers join the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and pass through the ciliary ganglion to the nasociliary and short ciliary nerves.

The vasoneurium supplies the nerve from outside to inside. As the somatic fibres are located in the inner part of the nerve, these fibres are affected more in the setting of ischemia. The parasympathetic pupillary fibres which run on the outside can remain unaffected (resulting in pupillary sparing). In compressive lesions, the parasympathetic fibres are affected before any disruption of the motor fibres. So pupillary sparing is not seen.

In INO, there is impaired adduction on the ipsilateral side of the lesion, and nystagmus on abduction on the contralateral side. When the gaze is initiated in the motor cortex, the horizontal gaze center or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements.
The PPRF has two outputs. The first is to the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus which causes abduction of the ipsilateral eye. The second output is to the contralateral MLF which sends an impulse to the contralateral 3rd cranial nerve nucleus causing contralateral adduction. These two outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side.
Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye, however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

Solution to Question 25:
Horizontal gaze palsy can occur due to a lesion in parapontine reticular formation (PPRF).
Horizontal gaze:
It involves 2 muscles- the ipsilateral lateral rectus and the contralateral medial rectus.
Center for this pathway is parapontine reticular formation (PPRF).
From here, they move to the ipsilateral 6th nerve nucleus.
Next, they pass through the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus.
Lesions affecting the abducens nuclei will also cause ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy, because of damage to motor neurons and internuclear neurons originating from the nuclei. Lesions involving the PPRF will lead to horizontal gaze palsy, as PPRF acts as a relay centre that connects the frontal eye fields in the cerebral cortex to the abducens nuclei. Conjugate horizontal gaze palsy can also be caused by lesion(s) involving both the abducens motor fibres and the MLFs preceding the abducens nucleus. Bilateral horizontal gaze palsy will be caused if lesion(s) involve both abducens nuclei or bilateral PPRF.
Isolated damage to the MLFs will cause the classic INO where eye abduction is preserved, however, the ipsilateral eye will not be able to be adducted on conjugate horizontal gaze.

Solution to Question 12:
Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of retinoblastoma. Knudson's hypothesis can be stated as follows:
Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB are required to produce retinoblastoma.
In familial retinoblastoma, one of the pair of alleles of RB1 is mutated in all the cells of the body. When a further mutagenic event ("second hit" according to the "two-hit" hypothesis proposed by Knudson) affects the second allele, the cell may then undergo malignant transformation. A large majority of these children develop bilateral and multifocal tumors.
In sporadic cases, both RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits).
Familial retinoblastoma patients also have a predisposition to non-ocular cancers because of the presence of the mutation in all cells, such as pinealoblastoma (usually before the age of 5 years), osteosarcomas, soft tissue sarcomas, and melanomas.
Note:
Trilateral retinoblastoma = Pinealoblastoma + Bilateral retinoblastoma

Solution to Question 25:
Photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve. This test is of particular use in early macular diseases such as central serous retinopathy.
In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again, and the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.
In normal people and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. Whereas, in patients with macular disease the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.

Solution to Question 9:
Cataract is not an ocular manifestation of dengue.
Dengue has varied manifestations, in different organ systems, mainly of inflammation and bleeding. Until recently, apart from retro-orbital pain, eye involvement was not recognized as a common feature of dengue infection. Potential pathogenic mechanisms include a direct viral effect on the eye, an immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to
dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements. Ocular manifestations of dengue:
Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis
Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

Solution to Question 11:
Iris pearls are pearly-white nodules seen on the iris in leprosy.
They are asymptomatic, 0.3 to 1.0 mm in diameter, dull yellowish-white in colour, and are seen at an early stage of the disease. It is not associated with any inflammatory changes in the anterior chamber. Histologically, it consists of lepromatous bacilli packed within mononuclear cells or acid-fast material with accompanying foreign body reaction. Inside the eye, leprosy bacilli preferentially lodge in the iris and ciliary body, due to the relatively cooler temperatures and high vascularity.

The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
The hallmark of Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal new vessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend into the vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous haemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied by pre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinal detachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.

The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

Solution to Question 1:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and the procedure is known as indirect ophthalmoscopy.
An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted, or reversed, real image of 2 to 5 times magnification.
The area of field in focus is about 8 disc diameters.
It is a binocular, self-illuminated device where the condensing lens is usually required, and stereopsis is present.
Solution to Question 2:
Indirect ophthalmoscope needs a binocular vision.
Solution to Question 3:
The image shows a slit lamp. Slit-lamp biomicroscopy is the ideal method to visualize the fundus, especially for observing the optic disc changes seen in glaucoma.
The lenses used are as follows:
Contact type: Goldmann three-mirror contact lens, modified Koeppe lens
Non-contact type: Convex lens à+60D, +78D, +90D (best lens)
Hruby lens: planoconcave lens with dioptric power of -58.6 D. Option B: The image given below shows a refractometer.

Option C: The image given below shows a keratometer

Option A: The image given below shows an ophthalmoscope

Solution to Question 4:
The pachymeter is used to measure corneal thickness.

Options A and D: A keratometer (ophthalmometer) measures the curvature of the anterior surface of the cornea at two points about 1.25 mm on either side of its center.

Option C: Specular microscopy is the study of the corneal endothelium under a very high magnification (100 times greater than slit lamp biomicroscopy). Endothelium can be analyzed for cellular size, shape, density, and distribution. The healthy endothelial cell is a regular hexagon, and the normal cell density in a young adult is about 3000 cells/mm2.

The image shows a Ziegler knife, which is used to open the lens capsule and aspirate the lens material in congenital cataract surgeries.
Solution to Question 6:
The given instrument is an indirect gonioscope, which is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber, i.e., for gonioscopy, and not the angle of the posterior chamber.
Types:
Indirect gonioprism- provides mirror image of the opposite angle.
Direct goniolens- provides a direct view of the angle Application:
To view the angle of the anterior chamber
Localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle
Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae
Direct goniolens can be used during goniotomy
Solution to Question 7:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is an ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).
It is a form of minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.
Ex-PRESS glaucoma implant is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap during a modified trabeculectomy. Complications such as hypotony are lower than with standard trabeculectomy.
Glaucoma drainage devices are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. While these devices were traditionally reserved for high-risk patients, or after trabeculectomy had failed, they are becoming increasingly popular.
The commonly used devices are as follows:
Shunts using episcleral explants
Ahmed glaucoma valve: Silicone
Molteno implant - Polypropylene plate and silicone plate
Baerveldt implant - Silicone
Mini-shunts
Ex-Press™ Mini-Shunt: Stainless stee
iStent® - Titanium
Solution to Question 8:
The image given above shows a Lister's perimeter. It is used in manual perimetry for visual field charting
Classification:
Manual: Confrontation, Listers, Campimetry, Goldmann perimeter
Automated: Octopus, Field Master, Humphrey Field Analyzer
Static: Friedman, Automated
Kinetic: Confrontation, Listers, Scotometry, Goldmann The best type is automated perimetry.
Solution to Question 9:
Tonopen is used for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea.
It is a hand-held electronic contact tonometer (a modified version of the older Mackay–Marg tonometer). Besides portability, its main advantage is the ability to measure IOP reasonably accurately in eyes with distorted or edematous corneas and through a soft contact lens.
Types of tonometry:
Indentation tonometry- Reading depends on scleral rigidity, e.g., Schiotz tonometer
Applanation tonometry- Based on the amount of force needed to flatten or applanate a known area of the cornea, Imbert–Fick principle. This is further divided into two types -
Fixed force: IOP is proportional to the area, e.g., Maklakov, Barraquer
Fixed area and variable force: IOP is proportional to force. The most reliable is Goldmann.
Self-measurement: Rebound
Non-contact type: Pulse Air, Air-Puff
Irregular cornea: Tonopen, MacKay–Marg Recent tonometers:
Pascals tonometer (dynamic contour tonometry [DCT]): Contact; used for post-LASIK IOP measurement.
Reichert Ocular Response Analyzer®: Non-contact
Note: Tonography is a non-invasive technique for determining the facility of aqueous outflow. The image given below shows fluorescein-stained semicircular mires.

Solution to Question 10:
Cataract surgery with an intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the treatment of choice in congenital cataracts. The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) used in such cases.
This surgery involves an extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary
posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy. After removal of the cataractous lens, a posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) is implanted.
PCIOL rest entirely behind the iris. They may be supported and fixed as follows:
Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method)
Ciliary sulcus fixation
Sclera fixation Parts of the IOL:
The central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic.
The peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization are the haptics. The image given below shows different types of intraocular lens.

Solution to Question 11:
The image depicts Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL). It is the most commonly used ACIOL.
Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angle of the anterior chamber. IOL implantation is the method of choice for correcting aphakia.
These are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy. The image given below shows different types of intraocular lens.

Solution to Question 12:
The given image depicts a Maddox wing. It is an instrument by which the amount of heterophoria for near vision can be measured.
Methods to examine heterophoria:
Testing for refractive error
Cover–uncover test
Prism bar cover test (PBCT)
Maddox rod test
Maddox wing test
Maddox tangent scale: heterophoria for distance
Measurement of the near point of convergence: Using RAF rule (Normally, it is 70 mm)
Measurement of fusional reserve- done with a synoptophore or prism bar

The image shows Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique) which is used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens.
Option A: Nagel’s anomaloscope is used to test color vision.

Option C: Maddox rod consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. Maddox rod test is a macular function test used to measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria in cases of torsional diplopia.

Option D: Retinoscope

Solution to Question 14:
The above instrument is a Maddox rod. Maddox Rod Test
A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.
A patient is asked to fix on a point light in the center of Maddox tangent scale placed 6 meters away. A Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye with the axis of the rod parallel to the axis of deviation. The patient will see a point light with one eye and a red line with the other. Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria in degrees.



Solution to Question 15:
Stenopaeic slit is not used for corneal tattooing.
Stenopaeic slit is an ophthalmological instrument that is used in:
Fincham’s test (Option A) : This test is used to differentiate between the colored halos due to immature cataract and corneal abnormalities such as corneal edema due to glaucoma.
To find out the axis in astigmatism (option D) for prescribing the correction glasses.
To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy (option C) for treating cases of central macular or leucomatous corneal opacities.
Corneal tattooing was done mainly in the past for cosmetic purposes. It is commonly done for firm scars of corneal opacities in a eye without any useful vision.

Solution to Question 16:
The given image depicts Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) of a normal macula.
It is a non-invasive, noncontact imaging system providing high-resolution cross-sectional images of the posterior segment. It uses near-infrared light interferometry to do so.
Solution to Question 17:
The given image depicts a duo-chrome test based on chromatic aberration. It is used to refine the final sphere in subjective refraction.
The patient is asked to compare the clarity of the letters on the green and the red side. If a myopic sees the letters of the green side clearer, he is overcorrected. So, +0.25 D sphere is added or
-0.25D is removed. However, if a myopic sees the letters on the red side clearer, he is undercorrected and -0.25 D sphere is added. With optimal spherical correction, the letters on the red and green halves of the chart appear equally clear.
Solution to Question 18:
An indirect ophthalmoscope produces a real, inverted and laterally reversed image of the fundus.
All the other instruments mentioned including direct ophthalmoscope, Hruby lens and Goldman contact lens produce a virtual and erect image of the fundus.

Solution to Question 20:
The image shows Hertel's exophthalmometer.
Exophthalmometry: measures protrusion of the apex of the cornea from the outer orbital margin
(with the eyes looking straight ahead).
An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labeled as proptosis.
Instruments used to measure proptosis:
Luedde exophthalmometer
Hertel’s exophthalmometer- most common instrument used. Its advantage is that it measures both eyes simultaneously.

Solution to Question 21:
The given instrument is a gonioscope.
It is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber (gonioscopy).
Types:
Indirect gonioprism- provides a mirror image of the opposite angle
Direct goniolens- provides a direct view of the angle Application:
To view the angle of the anterior chamber
Localization of foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle
Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae
Direct goniolens used during goniotomy
Solution to Question 22:
Retinoscopy is an objective method used to determine the error of refraction by applying the method of neutralization. It is also called skiascopy or shadow test.
Principle: When light is reflected from a mirror into the eye, the direction in which light will travel across the pupil will depend upon the eye's refractive state.
Distance: Usually, the doctor sits at a distance of 1 meter or an arm's length. Types of retinoscopes:
Priestley–Smith retinoscope
Streak retinoscope
